number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 27, 2013
												The Half-Life franchise has bought the gaming community many things, setting standards for countless others. Modding has been a big part of the attraction with games like Counter-Strike and Black Mesa spawning from the series. Hidden amongst them was a game by Unknown Worlds called Natural Selection, a cross between FPS and RTS. It was publicly released in late 2002 and was well received.Development of a sequel was announced back in 2006 and Natural Selection 2 was released very recently, keeping all key aspects from the original. The game focuses on two races; The Frontiersmen and the Kharaa.  The Frontiersmen are your classic space marines wielding guns and mechs. Kharaa on the other hand are microscopic life forms that spawn the units.On each team there's a "Commander", although slightly different for each team their main duties are coordinating the rest of the team, building structures and for the Kharaa, spreading infestation.As for the FPS elements, playing marine is everything you are used to with any other shooter. There is a "shop" system to acquire the new weapons and the mech as you play. The foot soldiers have to physically build the structures the commander plans and thus communication is vital.On the flip side, playing as the aliens is slightly different and more complicated. There are five "Classes". Everyone spawns as the basic skulk, a quick dog-like alien capable of climbing on walls and ceilings and being able to utilise ventilation systems as a quick way around the map. Their only form of attack is a bite. Once you have played for a short while you will be able to evolve into the other classes. Gorges are a support class, able to build walls and healing teammates. Then there is the flying Lerk, the stealthy Fade and the enormous Onos. Each have specific abilities such as flight, Blink and Door ramming respectively.The core gameplay is solid, it's heavily teamwork based and it has a good built-in communication system which makes it easy to work together. The engine was built from scratch for this very game and so it works as intended, I notice no bugs during my play time and the teams seem to be well balanced. The Kharaa seem to be more fun to play as but that may just be the greater speed and the unique traits of each evolution.The graphics look great and with a reasonable amount of customisation allowing for lower end computers to run it smoothly. There is a nice little rookie system that tells people that you may be new to the game and might need a little bit of help.It's not all great though, during a routine game playing as the Kharaa, a number of our team decided to leave. At this point, any other game would use matchmaking to fill the gaps however the game was abruptly ended giving an "Aliens Lose" message due to our lack of players. Something I wasn't expecting and it made me question the stability of further matches.The levels all seem very similar and finding your way around can be tricky. It's all set inside spaceship type corridors and rooms; I suppose to allow for the infestation spread. I found myself running round with the map overlay on just so I knew where I was going. I mean, It looks nice for spaceship hallways and the spread makes the landscape dynamic, and one I had been playing for a bit the map seemed pretty familiar.The loading may be painfully long but that is an issue that the developers are working on because it is due to a bug, but apart from that, getting into a game is very simple.Overall I really enjoyed the game, and it's something I see myself playing a lot of in the future.

content:
Posted: November 25, 2016
												Natural Selection 2 is an original and unique multiplayer game, great mix of RTS and FPS genres with a high requirement of teamwork. The opposing sides(Marines and Aliens) are very well balanced, though completely different. If you choose Marines, you will play   generic Team-Based FPS, but if you choose Aliens the game turns 180 degrees and brings you more Stealth/Action mechanics with a different classes. One player from each team taking role as the Commander, he is playing RTS part. He coordinates his team, deploying structures(actually ground troops have to build them), drop supplies and issuing orders; but not to SOME units, like in every RTS games, but to REAL PEOPLE. Yeah, wrap your head around that :) BUT BEWARE of its only and serious FLAW(in my opinion). Natural Selection 2 has ALMOST DEAD playerbase(which consists mostly of the same veteran players with a 1000+hours of play time, but don`t be afraid, there is a Rookie servers for you), for a Multiplayer Team-Based masterpiece, that is...very sad to say the least. Just keep that in mind before you consider to buy it.I recommend this game for its fun-factor and excitement i`ve got, and a mix of several game genres for this price is a great deal. Thanks for your attention and have a good day!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 26, 2012
												Does FPS finally meet RTS in a balanced amazing mix?This game is really interesting to me for two reasons:First of all it's a really solid FPS with tight and responsive controls.Secondly it's a really solid RTS with interesting upgrades and fun base building. Now that the meld of the two genres is out of the way, let's talk about how it works.The game is centred around two asymmetric teams; the aliens and the marines. Each team has a commander who will be playing the RTS game while the rest will be the "grunts" on the battlefield and play the FPS game. As you can probably imagine this requires a lot of teamwork and communication to work properly and give an interesting, fun match. The commander definitely has the most crucial and stressful job here, where the "units" won't necessarily follow orders. That certainly never happened in traditional RTS's.The asymmetric teams are really well balanced and the whole outset of the game just works flawlessly. The aliens are creepy and surprisingly varied in their different evolutions/classes, able to give the marines some great jump-scares by jumping out of nowhere as the invisible Fade or the many airducts scattered throughout the level.The marines are much more homogeneous, changing weapons and armour but of course staying in the same humanoid bodies.If you have fond memories of the Alien vs Predator franchise this might just be an amazing experience for you. The alien team can of course crawl on walls and ceilings as any proper alien creature needs to do, and the marines have large and loud weapons... by my descriptions you can probably tell which I enjoy playing more.The first couple of games are going to be incredibly confusing, so I'd definitely recommend watching some gameplay videos beforehand.

												I have played this game for about few hours and so far, what can I say about this game other than it really took me by surprise. content:
Posted: December 15, 2013
												Natural Selection 2 is a unique FPS and RTS combination type of game. It's a great game that requires RTS strategy in a teamwork FPS game. The graphics are decent but not too important as the game is really fast pace. The game is based on the typical Aliens vs Human fight and teamwork is neccessary. The maps are unique and mods make the gameplay last longer. Over time, resources are earned and can be spent on better weapons and units, which result in satifying kills. number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 21, 2013
												It's a great FPS-RTS hybrid with unique game mechanics and asymmetric gameplay. One player on each side takes the position of the commander and sees the battlefield like an RTS game. He issues commands and places structures that have to be build an defended by the other players. The other players see the world from the FPS perspective. This isn't CoD or BF! If a team doesn't work together, it usually gets crushed in a few minutes. So you really need to work together since there is no unit that can survive alone! I can't say this often enough! Remember to obey and help your commander and use your voice chat to report enemy movements etc!Playing as a human marine is similar to other shooters save for the team dependency. What really makes this game unique is the alien side. Since this game features asymmetric  gameplay, the developers made sure that the two teams play completely different. The aliens see the world through their mouth, bite and spit at enemies, climb walls, cloak and evolve into oher lifeforms.The game is incredibely fun if you play in a team that works together. Make sure to watch at least this short official tutorial before you start to play: 


YouTube™ Video: NS2 | Gameplay Overview Tutorial 

			Views: 38,196		

			http://store.steampowered.com/app/4920/ This is a basic gameplay primer for our hybrid shooter / strategy game Natural Selection 2

content:
Posted: November 29, 2012
												It's Natural Selection 2!  If you ever played the predecessor, a mod for Half-Life, then you are familiar with the concept.  It's a blend of some RTS elements into an FPS game, pitting aliens against humans.   As an Alien you can evolve to a number of different species, from flying Lerks to the massive bull-like Onos.   As a human, you're more limited by what your command chair player gives you.  They'll give you objectives for new structures to build, give you weaponry to equip yourself with, and research new tech for your team.The only gripe I have is with the balancing of the two sides, it's been disappointing at times in the beta and retail lifespan.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 16, 2012
												NS1 was an amazing experience. Built as a Half-Life Mod there was excitement when the Source Engine came out and people started to clamor for NS:Source. Work begain on NS:S but quickly the team realized that what they wanted to do was make their own engine and put out their own full release. NS2 is (finally) right around the corner. The long beta has been refining that NS experience that started back with that original Mod but has evovled into something so fresh and new while still having a comforting familiarity. The new engine is beautiful and creates a moody atmosphere that really emmerses the player either behind a rifle or behind a set of razor sharp teeth. The new engine isn't just to make things look pretty, there have been a number of gameplay elements that weren't possible before. But perhaps the most key element has remained in tact; the RTS/FPS hybrid. The ability for a player to jump into the commander role and give orders from a top down view makes Natural Selection 2 epic

content:
Posted: December 31, 2013
												It's certainly not the multiplayer experience everyone is after, and with no single-player component whatsoever, Natural Selection 2's appeal entirely depends on your desire for a complex, deep alternative to the usual immediacy of modern online shooters. There's potentially more balancing to be done when it comes to certain classes or abilities being slightly overpowered, but that's a matter of fine-tuned refinement rather than a vast overhaul. Right now it's an excellent game that taps into both the FPS and RTS markets, with plenty of varied builds and playing styles on offer. If competitive multiplayer gaming is survival of the fittest, then Natural Selection 2 is certainly fighting tooth and claw to reach the top tier."The humans are farting,and the monsters are barking!"

content:
Posted: July 24, 2014
												NS2 one of those games where even after hundreds of hours, I feel like I still kind of suck at it - but darn it, I'm still having lots of fun!It is an excellent game - maybe simple in concept, but beautifully executed. The alien side is novel and fascinating, and challenges you to think outside the box with tactics. On the marine side, you feel a hint of horror genre as you attempt to wreak righteous vengeance on the aliens invading your space station. Crucially, this game gets almost every aspect of its game mechanics right, in places where most other FPS-RTS combo games fail. Matches are generally of a satisfying length,  progress and change over time, and have plenty of room for pulling victory out of the jaws (get it?) of defeat when you're on the losing side. Balance, while an issue in every RTS-FPS combo, is better than most in the genre. Asymmetry is utilized to great effect. Teamwork is encouraged by the game mechanics.I do find myself switching to the combat mod at times when I get frustrated by permanently losing high-level characters due to a small mistake - I don't know if the learning curve can be improved or the frustation can be dampened but for now it's just par for the course, and makes it all the more thrilling when you pull off death-defying feats.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 29, 2013
												As a Half-Life fan, I heard of this mod long time ago - but never played it. I bought the new edition last year (mainly to support the developers) and was a bit scared by the fact that they built their own engine. After trying it out I was impressed by the visuals and gameplay, but unhappy with performance and mouse input. Because of that, the game did not draw my attention for too long.Lately, I gave NS2 a second chance and must admit that they put great effort into updates. You can use raw mouse input and the performance has increased dramatically. Furthermore the skill level is quite high (I think there is a competitive scene) and it is really fun to fool around as a total noob on public servers.The aiming skills needed are different (in comparision to e. g. Counter-Strike) because aliens are very fast, can be nearly everywhere and a lot of close combat situations arise. The RTS part of the game (commanding) seems to introduce a lot of cooperation and teamwork even to public servers.There are always full servers and the community is surprisingly friendly (voice communication is quite common). This is a great game, worth to buy even at full price - if you have time to play.

content:

												Well, in many ways this is a very well thought game. Though it isn't always easily accessible to new players. The maps are really good, but for a new player they are sometimes overwhelming. The little shortcuts for aliens e. g. are hardly noticeble as a marine. I mean, who never wanted to be an awesome alien rhino bashing through some humans and not giving a♥♥♥♥♥♥about their little be-be guns? The community is another point that really makes me wanna play this game. I can't remember to have seen a troll or anyone insulting their teammates or opponents. It feels like most people playing this game are actually mature and (how to game demands, but what doesnt seem to bother children in other games) 18+. So, if you have the motivation to find your way into a great game with an unconventional play-style and a one of the nicest communities I've seen so far, buy it. Maybe wait for sale, if you aren't completely sure, but if you search for mature players, this is the game to buy.Accessibilty: 5/10Gameplay: 8/10Community: 10/10

content:
Posted: January 1, 2013
												First Person Shooter crossed with an RTS. Marines Vs Aliens in a fight to take out the other's base. Each side is led by a commander who views the game in a Top-Down style RTS view. Their soldiers are controlled by other players in First-Person. Lots of weapons, upgrades, and equipment keep the game interesting depending on which order they are researched by the commander.Each team plays differently, but each also has an incredibly high learning curve. This game is not for the impatient or the lone-wolf. This is a team-based game. Players that don't work together will die, teams that are divided will lose. Coordination, communication, and tactics are far more valuable weapons than any Railgun or Onos.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 25, 2016
												Natural Selection 2 is an original and unique multiplayer game, great mix of RTS and FPS genres with a high requirement of teamwork. The opposing sides(Marines and Aliens) are very well balanced, though completely different. If you choose Marines, you will play   generic Team-Based FPS, but if you choose Aliens the game turns 180 degrees and brings you more Stealth/Action mechanics with a different classes. One player from each team taking role as the Commander, he is playing RTS part. He coordinates his team, deploying structures(actually ground troops have to build them), drop supplies and issuing orders; but not to SOME units, like in every RTS games, but to REAL PEOPLE. Yeah, wrap your head around that :) BUT BEWARE of its only and serious FLAW(in my opinion). Natural Selection 2 has ALMOST DEAD playerbase(which consists mostly of the same veteran players with a 1000+hours of play time, but don`t be afraid, there is a Rookie servers for you), for a Multiplayer Team-Based masterpiece, that is...very sad to say the least. Just keep that in mind before you consider to buy it.I recommend this game for its fun-factor and excitement i`ve got, and a mix of several game genres for this price is a great deal. Thanks for your attention and have a good day!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 29, 2012
												It's Natural Selection 2!  If you ever played the predecessor, a mod for Half-Life, then you are familiar with the concept.  It's a blend of some RTS elements into an FPS game, pitting aliens against humans.   As an Alien you can evolve to a number of different species, from flying Lerks to the massive bull-like Onos.   As a human, you're more limited by what your command chair player gives you.  They'll give you objectives for new structures to build, give you weaponry to equip yourself with, and research new tech for your team.The only gripe I have is with the balancing of the two sides, it's been disappointing at times in the beta and retail lifespan.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 15, 2013
												Consistent dev support. Official World Championship on going.All regular updates/new contents (including new maps, new weapons & new skills etc.) are FREE. Except skins & badges you get by donating to the Reinforcement Program, which actually helps a lot for the devs to keep everything else free.Very good visuals, sci-fi weapon & map design. Nice music.1 commander each side. Both human & alien team members play in first person view.No unlockables or progression system. You can play with everything right from the start as long as the commander builts/upgrades it in the match.Steep learning curve for regular FPS players.Could be very slow in every fresh start up (after system memory clean up). And the devs are still working on performance.PS:There's a basic turtorial for commander gameplay.Please be nice & patient to newer players especially when they are trying commander mode. If they're really dragging the whole team down just ask nicely & tell them how to exit the command center.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 19, 2013
												Simply and plainly one of the best FPS/RTS hybrid games available on the market.Where other games of this genre are lacking Natural selection 2 makes up for with unique a symetrical combat versus a vile alien race. Unlike most games of this type fighting against an enemy team of a COMPLETELY different makeup and abilities to your own makes quite interesting and pulse pounding games. Often ending is a very real struggle on both sides with team work, almost inherently making even the most random and public of games competitive.On top of this Natural Selection 2 is one of the few PC games that remains open source, coming with everything from the level designer to a PDF file explaining the dynamics of map making and how to make one that is balanced, the same PDF i assume Unknown worlds gives to their employees. Best of all, the developers take the time to listen to the community, engaging in conversation and discussions daily. In fact, being a player who has been around since early alpha i know a number of features in the game, good features, were designed by players like you are me and implemented with the help of the developers.Natural Selection 2 is a gem for its time, one of the last PC games to still embrace the community as PC games used to do.

												NS2 is a good old aliens vs humans game, with the aliens being feral creatures that want to spread their hive over the map.  This game involves you and your team trying to kill the other team (duh) while captureing reasource nodes and command stations.  Each team has their players who play in a first person perspective, either be the Marines who use their guns, jetpack, mech suits, or the Kharaa (aliens) with their abilities to run on walls or ceilings, spore rooms, and much more.  Both sides need a comander who plays from a bird's eye view leading the team, building, and reasurching improvements.  Overall this game is about team work and depending on teams, matchs go from 5 min to 45 min.  *Warning this game has a steep learning curve."

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 27, 2013
												The Half-Life franchise has bought the gaming community many things, setting standards for countless others. Modding has been a big part of the attraction with games like Counter-Strike and Black Mesa spawning from the series. Hidden amongst them was a game by Unknown Worlds called Natural Selection, a cross between FPS and RTS. It was publicly released in late 2002 and was well received.Development of a sequel was announced back in 2006 and Natural Selection 2 was released very recently, keeping all key aspects from the original. The game focuses on two races; The Frontiersmen and the Kharaa.  The Frontiersmen are your classic space marines wielding guns and mechs. Kharaa on the other hand are microscopic life forms that spawn the units.On each team there's a "Commander", although slightly different for each team their main duties are coordinating the rest of the team, building structures and for the Kharaa, spreading infestation.As for the FPS elements, playing marine is everything you are used to with any other shooter. There is a "shop" system to acquire the new weapons and the mech as you play. The foot soldiers have to physically build the structures the commander plans and thus communication is vital.On the flip side, playing as the aliens is slightly different and more complicated. There are five "Classes". Everyone spawns as the basic skulk, a quick dog-like alien capable of climbing on walls and ceilings and being able to utilise ventilation systems as a quick way around the map. Their only form of attack is a bite. Once you have played for a short while you will be able to evolve into the other classes. Gorges are a support class, able to build walls and healing teammates. Then there is the flying Lerk, the stealthy Fade and the enormous Onos. Each have specific abilities such as flight, Blink and Door ramming respectively.The core gameplay is solid, it's heavily teamwork based and it has a good built-in communication system which makes it easy to work together. The engine was built from scratch for this very game and so it works as intended, I notice no bugs during my play time and the teams seem to be well balanced. The Kharaa seem to be more fun to play as but that may just be the greater speed and the unique traits of each evolution.The graphics look great and with a reasonable amount of customisation allowing for lower end computers to run it smoothly. There is a nice little rookie system that tells people that you may be new to the game and might need a little bit of help.It's not all great though, during a routine game playing as the Kharaa, a number of our team decided to leave. At this point, any other game would use matchmaking to fill the gaps however the game was abruptly ended giving an "Aliens Lose" message due to our lack of players. Something I wasn't expecting and it made me question the stability of further matches.The levels all seem very similar and finding your way around can be tricky. It's all set inside spaceship type corridors and rooms; I suppose to allow for the infestation spread. I found myself running round with the map overlay on just so I knew where I was going. I mean, It looks nice for spaceship hallways and the spread makes the landscape dynamic, and one I had been playing for a bit the map seemed pretty familiar.The loading may be painfully long but that is an issue that the developers are working on because it is due to a bug, but apart from that, getting into a game is very simple.Overall I really enjoyed the game, and it's something I see myself playing a lot of in the future.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 29, 2013
												This game is a lot of fun. Its a wonderfull RTS/FPS hybrid, and the gameplay, especially with recent tweaks, is fast paced and exciting. Each team has a different playstyle, and the balance is set up very nicely. To list a few highlights:At the beginning of each round, a player on each team can enter the Command Center (Hive for Aliens) and is granted a top down perspective of the game, just like a standard RTS. The commander places buildings, purchases upgrades, and issues orders, just like an RTS.However, unlike a standard RTS, the units under his command do not have to follow orders, because these units are the other players. The other players play this game like a shooter, spending personal resources gained from building structures, killing enemies, and passively from secured resource points, to buy new weapons and equipment such as grenades for use.The Aliens, however, do not purchase weapons or equipment with their resources. They evolve into other life forms, spawning as the generic Skulk, a fast moving but fragile wolf-like creature, and evolve traits, like enhanced speed, armor, or stealth.One team wins if they destroy all of the other teams Command Posts/Hives.

content:
Posted: December 29, 2012
												Natural Selection 2 is an awesome cross between FPS and RTS, a RTFPSS if you will.  Each of the sides, Marine and Alien, have a commander that plays the RTS game, putting down buildings, managing upgrades and trying to direct the flow of battle; While all the other players on the team play the actual units.  Resources are harvested from certain points and go to both team resources that the commander spends and personal resources that can be used to buy weapons (for the marines) or evolve into new lifeforms (for the Kharaa).  The marines get the standard guns : starting with the machinegun and can purchase others such as a flamethrower, grenade launcher, welder or the ultimate Exo suit.  The Kharaa start as the skulk, angry little dogs, and can evolve into gorges (support/builder unit), Lerk (flying ranged unit), Fade (teleporting assassin) and finally the tanky Onos (large angry bull).  All in all it is a very fun game, and there is apparently a lot of moddability to the game as well so there is a lot of replay value.  I enjoy the game a lot and definitely recommend it.

content:
Posted: September 5, 2012
												I've got 732.7 hrs on record for this game (from closed beta), and I fully expect to have well over 2000 in the next year or two. This is a VERY RARE title. It blends so many elements from FPS, RTS, and even have mechanics from other genres like adventure games. NS2 captures the thrills of FPS combat, the tactical intruige of RTS, and the joy of winning in a team-based game. It can have some learning issues for new players, but once it clicks, once you understand the awesomeness of NS2, you will keep coming back again and again.There is no single-play version, but there eventually will be due to how insanely moddable this game is. The entire custom engine was built with modding in mind. It has Steam Workshop support for maps, but will soon include support for full mods. Spark (the Engine/Platform NS2 runs on), dare I say, is more moddable than the original HL1 and look what came from it. The potential for entirely new games, variations of NS2 make this worth the price alone. Get it!!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 29, 2013
												This game is a lot of fun. Its a wonderfull RTS/FPS hybrid, and the gameplay, especially with recent tweaks, is fast paced and exciting. Each team has a different playstyle, and the balance is set up very nicely. To list a few highlights:At the beginning of each round, a player on each team can enter the Command Center (Hive for Aliens) and is granted a top down perspective of the game, just like a standard RTS. The commander places buildings, purchases upgrades, and issues orders, just like an RTS.However, unlike a standard RTS, the units under his command do not have to follow orders, because these units are the other players. The other players play this game like a shooter, spending personal resources gained from building structures, killing enemies, and passively from secured resource points, to buy new weapons and equipment such as grenades for use.The Aliens, however, do not purchase weapons or equipment with their resources. They evolve into other life forms, spawning as the generic Skulk, a fast moving but fragile wolf-like creature, and evolve traits, like enhanced speed, armor, or stealth.One team wins if they destroy all of the other teams Command Posts/Hives.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 4, 2014
												You remember the Alien vs. Predator frenchise back in the day? Before Half Life 2? This is it at it's core. And then, it isn't.Natural Selection 2 is a competitive FPS-RTS mix that features asymmetrical gameplay. A team of Marines is put against a team of aliens that play entirely different while one player of each team serves as an overseeing commander from a top-down perspective. As commander you have to put down buildings like ressource extractors, armories, robotic facilities or buildings that provide upgrades for your little and ever complaining servants. This mode actually plays quite a lot like Starcraft or Command & Conquer for example. At least most of the times. You can even issue specific orders to individual team members. Following these orders and the way they are executing them is completely up them though.While the commander and his skill is certainly critical to the success of your team, the personal skill of every soldier/alien matters almost as equally. But teamplay is objectively the most critical. A team that communicates a steady flow of information is already half way through the match.There is quite a lot of maps shipped with the game and an almost infinite number of custom made maps as well as different game modes. The basic mode though puts you on a map with usually 5 locations where a command terminal or hive can be set up. These are needed for your commander to do his job. If you loose all of your Command terminals / Hives you loose the game. You start with one prebuild at a random location together with your first ressource extractor that provide a slow tick of ressources, both for the commander to spend on buildings, upgrades etc and for every player seperately to spend on personal equipment (Weapons, Armor, perks, ...). In case of the Marines you also start with a single Infantry Portal on which dead marines can respawn. Aliens hatch from eggs that spawn near a Hive at a slow rate.So the immediate goal is to expand to other ressource nodes, build up you base and defend it and eventually destroy the enemie's bases. It's a game about map control like you would expect from a competitive RTS, so usually the team that holds the majority of ressource nodes for an extended period of time wins the game. Usually.So much for the gameplay. What's it mechanically? It's a fast paced shooter that orientates itself along older titles like said Alien vs. Predator, Unreal Tournament, even Counter Strike for a certain degree. Weapons don't nessecarily act realistically. It is more important to keep the cursor on target than it is precisely aim or shoot in bursts to maintain a narrow spread. Aliens regenerate health at a slow rate but marines need medipacks that are dropped by the commander or an armory to get back up to full health. In addition they need a teammate with a welder to fix any armor points lost.So, pretty old school but with an interesting twist and certainly a focus on teamplay.Gameplay mechanics for the commander are deskribed in one word: Starcraft. It's an established formula and it works fine. Hotkeys, hotkeys, hotkeys. Every building and every equipment you may drop as commander is sorted in different categories (basic buildings, advanced buildings, etc.) and mapped to a specific key. (Controls are fully rebindable by the way). That's it. It's pretty easy to pick up although quite hard to be good at.Technically and graphically the game is not really state of the art. It is not an ugly game and the texture quality is reasonably good. Animations work fine although they might look a bit silly from time to time. Where it really shines is it's dense, almost claustrophobic atmosphere and the ammount of adjustable game and graphics options as well as it featuring a good, old fashioned server browser and full mod support.It's a PC game so why would you not want to pick a server based in your country with a low ping instead of being randomly assigned some server at the end of the world where not a single person speaks a language you recognise and you lag yourself through the map? Server browsers are your best friend in any FPS and Natural Selection 2 has one so... go for it.If you like Counter Strike but would like to try something that puts two teams with entirely different strengthes and weaknesses against each other while maintaining a high degree of competitive gameplay then Natural Selection 2 is a thing you will most certainly enjoy.If you already enjoyed it's predecessor or Alien vs. Predator back in the day but the graphics get a bit old for you then this is an absolute no-brainer. Buy it. Love it.One thing to keep in mind though is that the developer pretty much ceased any support and further development to be able to concentrate on their current project. Although there are still frequent content updates and plenty of bugfixes provided by the community team that officially took over and so far the changes that were made by this team improved the game in many aspects.

content:
Posted: July 20, 2014
												Probably the most challenging FPS you've ever played. The different enemy types, the different abilities, and the extremely fast pace mixed with potentially hour-long matches make every second count, and every decision by the team and the commander a question of life or death (Well, win or loss). Don't go into this game expecting to be a god, but expect that by the time you're good at it (I'm not), you'll be able to play almost any other FPS with the competitive and tactical advantage that comes from having to think strategically on your feet as well as point the gun (or jaws) in the right direction at the right time before you chomp down (or pull the trigger).

												played linux version.Nice game concept, lots of fun.Some minor bugs (crashes, ignoring mouse/keyboard events) which i hopethey will solve eventually.The only real negative is the influence of lag of server/players and how theengine reacts with it wrongly: the location of the enemy you see is differentfrom the server and different from that player itself. However it seems hittingthe player from your view does count, but moving in a clear space which is reallyoccupied does not. This causes frustration when trying to move around or dodgean enemy and you can't. Also players with high ping have a slight advantage as theysee other players move in a forseen path and can hit them eassier.Experienced players take this into account, but it is a steep learning curve.

content:
Posted: November 16, 2012
												This is a pretty awesome game.You play as either an Alien or as a Marine. Marines like to use guns, Aliens like to nom Marines and are faster. Both sides have a commander who builds structures for the team and play this FPS as an RTS instead. They use resources from resource points that they've built on or gotten team-mates to build on. These then are used to get more tech and upgrades for everyone else.Everyone else also gets resources from their controlled resource points. Aliens use them to evolve into different Aliens (and to place structures as Gorge) such as rhinos (Onos), whilst Marines use them to get different guns and jetpacks and mechs.So your goal is to eliminate all the enemy players by either destroying their respawn buildings and/or command structures. To do this hold more resource points so you get upgrades faster, and go destroy enemy buildings / people with better weapons/aliens so that the enemy team loses their resources.Have fun nomming people/shooting things/bossing people around!

content:
Posted: December 14, 2012
												Awesome multiplayer FPS/RTS/Stealth game pitting the Marines against the alien race Kharaa.Good co-op is extremely important with the marines having different infantry weapons (all of which are good in their own right and have their own drawbacks) such as assault rifle- shotgun- grenade launcher- flamethrower- and the Exo which is a big, tough but slow armored walker sporting 1 or 2 hard hitting chainguns.Also includes support items for infantry such as welders for repairing structures and infantry and Exo armor. And jet-packs to greatly enhance the speed and mobility of infantry.This put up against the Kharaa's arsenal of lifeforms including:The small, fast moving, wall and celing crawling SkulkThe support and builder-class GorgeThe flying and obnoxious gas-farting LerkThe in-and-out-of-battle blinking assassin-class FadeAnd the massive and extremely tough marine-stomping and goring Onos.But there's more!! Both sides are critically dependent on a competent commander viewing it all from an RTS point of view, setting up structures, researching upgrades, new gear and abilities, dropping supplies in times of need and advicing the forces in their quest to destroy the enemy. Will you be that one commander leading your team to victory?? You're not even my real father!!!!! ♥♥♥♥ YOU ♥♥♥♥ YOU ♥♥♥♥ YOU!!!!!!More here http://naturalselection.wikia.com/wiki/Kharaa_%28Natural_Selection_2%29

content:
Posted: January 4, 2014
												This is a very fun and addictive game, and the graphics are fantastic. My only problem with it is that there are not many options available to reduce draw times, for lower end PCs like mine, meaning that I rarely get a slightly decent framerate of even 20 frames per second on my machine. I can't complain because the developer's aren't to blame for my PC being terrible, but I would have liked to see more features able to be adjusted like texture quality and geometric complexity, since reducing the triangle count would certainly speed up draw times and make the game a lot more playable for people with less expensive machines like mine. Anyway, with that issue aside, the game is still very impressive and if it's on sale, I'd say go for it if you've got a nice GPU.

The game is great but the community suffers from a god complex where the best players on servers believe anyone who hasn't the time or skill they do to master the game are way beneath them and don't deserve to play.The servers and players have gone the way of an elementary school dodgeball game where the fewest hours played gets picked last (literally the players on servers say to wait until you are picked to join a team) and the players riff on you until you are tired of hearing ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t from all of them.Honestly, I love the developers and this game but the community has gone to absolute♥♥♥♥♥♥  Unless the developers can do something about the♥♥♥♥♥♥players save your money for something better.TL;DR Love the game but the community has gone the way of Left 4 Dead 2.EDIT: It's been 3 years since I've been playing this game and shuffle helps with the mentality described above but since the community is so small it can suffer from very visible bad eggs. content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												Natural Selection 2 is a fun game. It is an asymmetrical FPS. There are some potitives and negatives to that. On one hand, it is uniquely different. Not like something I've played before. On the other hand, the asymmetry makes it difficult to balance. The marines are your standard FPS type. A human that uses guns. They have technology that helps them against the aliens. Stuff like phase gates, shotguns, and jetpacks.The aliens are the things that throw a wrench in it all. Highly mobile and none of them use guns. The aliens evolve upgrades and evolve into other aliens that suit the job.Some people report poor performance, but it works fine on my machine.I'd recommend picking it up for under $10.I will update this review to be more in-depth at a later time.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 15, 2013
												Should you buy Natural Selection 2?So firstly, what is Natural Selection 2?Natural Selection 2 is a multiplayer only, Strategy/FPS hybrid (a mixture of the strategy and first person shooter genres) created by Unknown Worlds, in which marines face off against aliens in a fight for map domination. It was origonally a mod for Half-Life published over 10 years ago. One player from each team elects to be commander and plays the game similar to a real time strategy. All the other players either become a marine or an alien (depending on the team a player is on) and plays the game in a more FPS style.What is the gameplay like?Natural Selection 2 is not an easy game by any means. It relies heavily on teamwork as well as personal skill. The most critical roles in the game is the commander as he/she is responsible for co-ordinating the team, placing structures, managing resources and choosing upgrades. For this reason, it is highly recommended that people new to the game (< 10 hours) do not command on public servers. Moving on, marines play like most other FPS's, with their primary weapon being a gun. Everyone spawns in as a marine and can buy weapons and utilities from structures such as armories. When a marine is killed, he/she respawns from one of the infantry portals placed by the commander. As for the aliens, everyone spawns in as a basic alien call a skulk. Skulks have the ability to run up walls and bite for their primary attack. An alien can also evolve (works similar to buying) into other life forms. These other life forms consist of the gorge (an engineer/medic support life form), the lerk (a flying alien with ranged attacks), the fade (an assassin like alien which can use "blinking" to move very fast) and the onos (a big rhino looking creature). When an alien dies, he/she becomes one of the team's eggs around a hive (an alien command structure) and hatches after a few seconds. The game is heavily resource based, with each team battling for the numerous resource nodes scattered around the map. Because of this, the balance of power can snowball if a team gets a poor start. Games usually last for around 20 minutes, although there is always the odd 1 hour long games (which are usually very tense).Do I recommend this game?I would recommend this game to anyone if they are intrested in games in the strategy and FPS genre. However, this game requires quite a few hours to grasp the concepts and its community is slowly shrinking, so if you have friends who have lots of spare time of their hands, it might be worth picking this up during a sale and giving it a go. (Plus playing with friends is always lots more fun)Pros:Asymmetrical gameplayGood mix of RTS and FPSCons:Steep learning curveSmall community

content:
Posted: December 14, 2012
												Awesome multiplayer FPS/RTS/Stealth game pitting the Marines against the alien race Kharaa.Good co-op is extremely important with the marines having different infantry weapons (all of which are good in their own right and have their own drawbacks) such as assault rifle- shotgun- grenade launcher- flamethrower- and the Exo which is a big, tough but slow armored walker sporting 1 or 2 hard hitting chainguns.Also includes support items for infantry such as welders for repairing structures and infantry and Exo armor. And jet-packs to greatly enhance the speed and mobility of infantry.This put up against the Kharaa's arsenal of lifeforms including:The small, fast moving, wall and celing crawling SkulkThe support and builder-class GorgeThe flying and obnoxious gas-farting LerkThe in-and-out-of-battle blinking assassin-class FadeAnd the massive and extremely tough marine-stomping and goring Onos.But there's more!! Both sides are critically dependent on a competent commander viewing it all from an RTS point of view, setting up structures, researching upgrades, new gear and abilities, dropping supplies in times of need and advicing the forces in their quest to destroy the enemy. Will you be that one commander leading your team to victory?? You're not even my real father!!!!! ♥♥♥♥ YOU ♥♥♥♥ YOU ♥♥♥♥ YOU!!!!!!More here http://naturalselection.wikia.com/wiki/Kharaa_%28Natural_Selection_2%29

												played linux version.Nice game concept, lots of fun.Some minor bugs (crashes, ignoring mouse/keyboard events) which i hopethey will solve eventually.The only real negative is the influence of lag of server/players and how theengine reacts with it wrongly: the location of the enemy you see is differentfrom the server and different from that player itself. However it seems hittingthe player from your view does count, but moving in a clear space which is reallyoccupied does not. This causes frustration when trying to move around or dodgean enemy and you can't. Also players with high ping have a slight advantage as theysee other players move in a forseen path and can hit them eassier.Experienced players take this into account, but it is a steep learning curve.

content:
Posted: June 3, 2014
												pros: asymmetrical factions, gameplay with depth, a great blend of fps and rts, good video options menu and visuals, great soundtrack, the tech tree for aliens shows the evolution and tech trees available to the player during a game, great server browser menu cons: steep learning curve with a weak tutorial, difficult to navigate (you have to constantly bring up the mini map to find where you are and the map icons look messy), the tech tree for marines isn't readily available to see during a gameOverall, a great game concept executed very well - but fails to fully tackle the steep learning curve that new players face. The expansive map design is one of this game's strength but also one of its greatest weakness.Natural Selection 2 is a hit or miss.

												Probably the most challenging FPS you've ever played. 												Should you buy Natural Selection 2?So firstly, what is Natural Selection 2?Natural Selection 2 is a multiplayer only, Strategy/FPS hybrid (a mixture of the strategy and first person shooter genres) created by Unknown Worlds, in which marines face off against aliens in a fight for map domination. It was origonally a mod for Half-Life published over 10 years ago. One player from each team elects to be commander and plays the game similar to a real time strategy. All the other players either become a marine or an alien (depending on the team a player is on) and plays the game in a more FPS style.What is the gameplay like?Natural Selection 2 is not an easy game by any means. It relies heavily on teamwork as well as personal skill. The most critical roles in the game is the commander as he/she is responsible for co-ordinating the team, placing structures, managing resources and choosing upgrades. For this reason, it is highly recommended that people new to the game (< 10 hours) do not command on public servers. Moving on, marines play like most other FPS's, with their primary weapon being a gun. Everyone spawns in as a marine and can buy weapons and utilities from structures such as armories. When a marine is killed, he/she respawns from one of the infantry portals placed by the commander. As for the aliens, everyone spawns in as a basic alien call a skulk. Skulks have the ability to run up walls and bite for their primary attack. An alien can also evolve (works similar to buying) into other life forms. These other life forms consist of the gorge (an engineer/medic support life form), the lerk (a flying alien with ranged attacks), the fade (an assassin like alien which can use "blinking" to move very fast) and the onos (a big rhino looking creature). When an alien dies, he/she becomes one of the team's eggs around a hive (an alien command structure) and hatches after a few seconds. The game is heavily resource based, with each team battling for the numerous resource nodes scattered around the map. Because of this, the balance of power can snowball if a team gets a poor start. Games usually last for around 20 minutes, although there is always the odd 1 hour long games (which are usually very tense).Do I recommend this game?I would recommend this game to anyone if they are intrested in games in the strategy and FPS genre. However, this game requires quite a few hours to grasp the concepts and its community is slowly shrinking, so if you have friends who have lots of spare time of their hands, it might be worth picking this up during a sale and giving it a go. (Plus playing with friends is always lots more fun)Pros:Asymmetrical gameplayGood mix of RTS and FPSCons:Steep learning curveSmall community

content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												Natural Selection 2 is a fun game. It is an asymmetrical FPS. There are some potitives and negatives to that. On one hand, it is uniquely different. Not like something I've played before. On the other hand, the asymmetry makes it difficult to balance. The marines are your standard FPS type. A human that uses guns. They have technology that helps them against the aliens. Stuff like phase gates, shotguns, and jetpacks.The aliens are the things that throw a wrench in it all. Highly mobile and none of them use guns. The aliens evolve upgrades and evolve into other aliens that suit the job.Some people report poor performance, but it works fine on my machine.I'd recommend picking it up for under $10.I will update this review to be more in-depth at a later time.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 3, 2013
												Probably has got to be one of my favorite multiplayer shooter games. I highly recommend those that are into both shooters and strategy based games. The game basically has 2 different teams, alien and marine. Both teams has it's own unique abilities and types of gameplay with the aliens ranging more around melee, and the marines towards long range weaponry. There is a commander on each team responsive for helping their team win by providing upgrades, expansion of territory, and supporting players.There are plenty of different modes within the game. From normal NS2 mode to modes such as combat and much more.One problem is that if you have a old or not so great computer, you may experience massive lag. I'll highly recommend those with newer more stronger computers to only buy this game otherwise the lag can become increasively annoying to both the player and others playing on the servers.But other than that I think this game is worth the buy and incredibly fun and addicting!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 15, 2013
												A visceral and fast paced multiplayer shooter combined with real time strategy make for Natural Selection's strengths. Gameplay involves either being on the ground or in the commander's seat, fusing beautifully the first person shooter and the real time strategy genres.Numerous weapons and classes are available for both the Marines and the Kharaa, this allows for diverse play and keeps the game interesting. From the humble skulk, running on the ceilings and dropping in on unsuspecting victims. To the gargantuan and brutish Onos, smashing everything in it's path and reducing Marine machines to their component parts in seconds. There's a class for all kinds of players on both sides. Want to run around fearing for your life? Stick with your bog-standard infantryman. Want to go crazy and toe-to-toe with an Onos? Get yourself a mech and be feared by the Kharaa.WIth hours of replayability, servers up 24/7, and a well balanced system of play. Natural Selection 2 is by far one of my favourite games of all time. Go ahead, buy it. I'll be waiting on the ceiling round the corner.

content:
Posted: January 4, 2014
												This is a very fun and addictive game, and the graphics are fantastic. My only problem with it is that there are not many options available to reduce draw times, for lower end PCs like mine, meaning that I rarely get a slightly decent framerate of even 20 frames per second on my machine. I can't complain because the developer's aren't to blame for my PC being terrible, but I would have liked to see more features able to be adjusted like texture quality and geometric complexity, since reducing the triangle count would certainly speed up draw times and make the game a lot more playable for people with less expensive machines like mine. Anyway, with that issue aside, the game is still very impressive and if it's on sale, I'd say go for it if you've got a nice GPU.

												I really enjoy this game and the way it works. You can play two different games while on the battlefield or in the commander position. It has a complex system of fighting, offering 5 different Alien classes, and a variety of guns from a rifle to a grenade launcher. You even have the option to use an Exosuit as the Marines.I have had many fun times playing this game, and even if you are 100% new, you can have fun experiences being the terrified marine noobie, or just running around chompin on some nerds as a skulk. I feel this game is widely enjoyable to most people, I completely recommend you pick this game up and try it youself!

Posted: September 6, 2014
												I used to love this game in the last 2 years: but it has become something different.  The game is great but the community suffers from a god complex where the best players on servers believe anyone who hasn't the time or skill they do to master the game are way beneath them and don't deserve to play.The servers and players have gone the way of an elementary school dodgeball game where the fewest hours played gets picked last (literally the players on servers say to wait until you are picked to join a team) and the players riff on you until you are tired of hearing ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t from all of them.Honestly, I love the developers and this game but the community has gone to absolute♥♥♥♥♥♥  Unless the developers can do something about the♥♥♥♥♥♥players save your money for something better.TL;DR Love the game but the community has gone the way of Left 4 Dead 2.EDIT: It's been 3 years since I've been playing this game and shuffle helps with the mentality described above but since the community is so small it can suffer from very visible bad eggs.  I have a love hate relationship with this game where it holds a very special place in my heart for games but the community can still occasionally put me off bad enough to drop the game for months.  I still can't help coming back though.Not sure what to say about it.  The community can be great for a majority of the time so most of the time you may not have an issue but those bad nights can be pretty offputting to a new game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 15, 2014
												Natural Selection 1 is my favorite competitive/cooperative multiplayer shooter of all time. Natural Selection 2 is a fantastic continuation of the franchise. The main draw of the game is that there are two asymmetric teams, the colonial space marines vs. the zerg-like Khara. The space marines have to take locations and fight with the Khara over resource points. Both teams play primarily like most shooters in a first person perspective, however both teams also have a commander who views the map from a top down, RTS-like view. The commander's job is to give his team orders, build various structures, and plan out strategies against the opposing force. This sounds complicated, and initially it is very difficult to play. Natural Selection 2 has a very dedicated, albeit small community who have been playing this game for a long, long time. Therefore they are often a little dickish to newcomers who come into the game, since the weakest link in a chain can cause them all to fail. However, if you make an active effort to learn the mechanics and strategies required, you'll be having a lot of fun working with your team, either setting up ambushes in dark places as the wall-climbing skulk or burning away alien structures with a flamethrower. The team synergy that is capable in this game is the best in any multiplayer game, but due to the complexity and the steep learning curve most people who try out this game never find it.It's a shame that Natural Selection 2 has been operating at a bit of a loss for Unknown Worlds, since a bunch of their keys got stolen and sold on illicit websites. This game goes on sale for $2.99 and was in a couple of Humble Bundles, so it should be pretty darn cheap to purchase. Everyone should at least try it out for that price, and who knows, maybe it'll be your new favorite multiplayer game!Tip for noobs playing as Khara: Go gorge and build/heal everything. Try not to think too much about it. Tip for noobs playing as spess mehrens: Follow large groups of soldiers around and watch your back. Use your flashlight to look into corners/ on the top of doorways where the Khara like to ambush from. Buy a welder when you can and focus on repairing structures/ your teammate's armor.

												If there was ever a game with potential to become THE new esports title, then NS2. However it couldn't create a hype like csgo and so its a game with a fairly small community. With the recent addition of a marine commander tutorial and the announcement of a tutorial for the alien commander, there will hopefully be more good commanders out there. 												There isn't a game out there quite like this. This game mixes the RTS and FPS genres perfectly, and it offers an experience no other game to date has been able to touch. Perhaps best of all, this experience is just $10 away, something most people spend at their favorite burger joint almost daily.Do yourself a favor and buy this game. number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 21, 2013
												---this review happened to be a long review. but i wrote down everything i thought about this game after 1500+ hours of gameplay, plus NS1 experience. first part is why you should buy the game. what makes the game so fun. second portion is about 'the reason why this game did not become one of the best selling game eventhought i praise this game in the first portion of the review'do you like Starcraft? do you like FPS games? then this game is a go for you. This is a few FPS game in current market that you cannot just YOLO to win a round. You actually have to think, plan, many steps before the enemy. this game also requier multitasking skill. while you are rushing to your objective, while you are shotting at aliens, you re required to know what's happening in each location on the map.(if you can't do that, usually there are people with mic that inform you which room is being hit and which room is clear to move in and so on)commanding is a whole differnt part of the game. you cannot just jump in the command chair without much experience as a field marine for good couple of hundreds of hours of gameplay time in NS2, but ironically, you do need to have experiences as a commander to understand the physiology of the game.after that, you are supposed to think as a commander, do what commander would want a marine to do, when you are a field marine. that's how you win a game as a solid team, and that's the true jewel of this game.this is what makes NS2 the best game i've ever played in my life, and trust me, i've been a  PC gamer for about 15 years. this teamwork requirement environment, this strategy heavy gamestyle is unparalleled to any other game with the same or similar expirence.the only flaw is that UWE, the developer of this game, is a small company, plus they have been making terrible mistakes for the past year. and they might make more mistakes in the future because that's who they are.1.they forced themselves to develop their own engine eventhough they lack human, capital resources. which is why it took years years for NS2 to be released.2.due to #1, the game engine is very poorly coded and thus poorly optimized to any computer system. if you get 120FPS in BF4, expect to get 60FSP in this game at most.3.there are only handful number of maps that are actually playable. there are custom made maps in workshop, but i've never seen a single map that is actually balanced and playable.(including jambi. jambi is the best custom map but at the same time, it's still unplayable) and UWE didn't care about having only 6 maps because they have less then 10 employee in their company, and they decided to spend their time on developing new mods(that is also broken to maximum level) changing balance here and there(that were unnecessary), changing maps(i mean ruining maps like docking), fixing bugs(thus making more bugs by the bugfix)4.the game is unbalanced to public players since UWE only focus everything in the game for 6 vs 6 competitive matches. the best experience i had while playing this game was when i was playing in 30+, 40+ servers. but i'm not sure if UWE knows that they can't optimize the game to that level of server environment, or they really want to make this game like starcraft that pro  players compete in national league, but if you join a server that is 20+, you will notice that alien vs marine balance is broken. it's always marines that are stronger because they have guns, when both alien, and marine players are at exactly same level when it comes to skills and teamwork. i used to be ok with that. this asymmetric confrontation was what i loved the move about this game. the problem arose when UWE started to nerf down aliens and give marines more and more weapons, and more firepowers.5.the game is laggie to its maximum level. you will notice that you actually get killed not because of your skill, but because of the lag issue. if you have 200+ ping, you will be almost a solid second behind what's really going on in the server. this is very ironic if you recall what i said about balancing. UWE is going for 6 vs 6 player balancing because they want to see more and more competitive matches and leagues, thus making 20+ server unbalanced. and i hear competitive league players complaining that they can't compete with other teams at their best condition because of the lag issue. the reason why it sounds like i'm ranting every single thing about UWE is because i realized that it's in their nature. even though they are given with this awesome game concept, the execution was a fail, and i must say, they could have done something to prevent this. they could have become next blizzard. they could have made it next starcraft. they could have make the competitions shown on TV like starcraft. but UWE has failed and that's why you see 75% off sale every month for past 5 months. UWE finally accepted their failure. and the last thing i want to point out is that they started a donation program toward UWE at the same time as they started to promote the game with 75% sales. the company has some serious moral hazard. they chand the gameplay style upside down 6 months after the release and they've been doing that once a while, and oldbies like myself was thinking 'this is not what i've purchased, this is not what i've been trying so hard to be good at'.Conclusion:the strongest iron happened to meet its least skilled blacksmith. you will still have fun with it. but expect some flaws. and after playing awhile, you will face a unclimbablely stiff learning curve due to the game engine and lag.(you don't have to worry about this for the first couple of hundreds of hours because the game's learning curve is stiff at the beginning too)

												Pros:+ Great atmosphere and graphics+ Awesome team-based gameplay+ Controls are very smooth and the framerates are smooth as well+ Very fun mix of countersrike, starcraft, and aliens vs predatorCons:- Very first match once you boot up the game has slightly longer load times- Steep learning curve (but gives you a huge sense of reward once you get into the groove)Preferred peripheral: Keyboard and Mouse (not sure if it works with a gamepad)Personal Notes:One of the most fun team-based games I have ever played. content:
Posted: May 8, 2014
												I have a hard time deciding on whether I love this game or hate it.  I was an avid player of the original Natural Selection late in it's lifetime.  The RTS-esque elements of NS2 are done very well, but they should provide you with an in-game tutorial to help guide you with the how-to's and when-to's of this element of the game.  Playing as the marines is basically a straight forward shooter. Where the game really seperates itself from the pack are playing as the aliens and the surprising amount of team work shown by members of the community playing this game.  I was very impressed with the community.  If you are seeking a different take on competitive FPS multiplayer games and a decently steep but short learning curve then this is the game for you!

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 15, 2014
												Natural Seclection 2 is half First Person Shooter, half stategy game of space marines vs aliens. It really is a unique game because you can become a commander for your team like true real time strategy. However, I recommend that you NEED to wear headphones while playing. The commander and players like to use mics while communicating. So it will be hard to listen if you're just using speackers. Natural Selection 2 focuses on teamwork. So you cannot go guns blazing through the game like callofduty. Otherwise your team will lose altogether. You must trust and follow your commander's orders to win the game.Overall: 8/10The gameplay is one of a kind. You will not find a game like this. It's unique style is worth buying.

content:
Posted: November 6, 2016
												If you've ever thought to yourself when playing an RTS, "Sometimes I'd just really like to be one of the little minions or badass units engaged in the carnage," then this is the game for you.  It has a unique RTS strategy element where one player is the commander, setting goals and researching upgrades, and the rest are foot soldiers carrying out orders and slinging bullets (or slime).  And you can transition between either style seamlessly in the middle of a game too.The game is beautiful, has a pretty good player base, is easy to pop in and out of, and is loads of fun.The only downside is the learning curve, especially for the Aliens, but if you do the tutorials (and maybe a little research on the side, depending on how elite you want to be), you'll be just fine.Enthusiastically recommend this title.  One of the few I've never once regretted spending money on.

												Fun and addicting game play. Great moments in game where you pull off a perfect strategy or ambush. Even scary moments to when going up against 'human' alien players too (lights go out and you hear growling). Evolve and research mechanics add a fun dynamic to the games session. Posted: April 14, 2014
												This game is a nice update of the original and it's very multiplayer friendly, sadly the community isn't that friendly and for casual players a pain in the♥♥♥♥♥ Most of the time you will face stacked teams over several rounds as this game somewhat developed its  own way of targeting, it's unusually hard to hit in this game. As a marine you don't just simply shoot straight forward, and as an alien you have to use your surroundings to your advantage to bounce of walls and attack from above.Next to this, the original creators abandoned the game and left us with a CDT, that manages to break more and more stuff with every bigger update, claiming that they fix bugs and upgrade the performance.Since over a year now, there's a reload bug in the game they haven't fixed and with the last update, they broke the player placed tunnels (Just to give you a few examples)The game runs heavily unstable, your fps goes up and down like on a rollercoaster and the not-so-rare crashes sometimes are that massive, that'll freeze up your PC completly.

content:
Posted: June 23, 2016
												Natural Selection 2 is a really good game. It is a MOBA like where the ennemy team has to destroy all of the ennemies command things to win. It is a multiplayer game wich you either play as a marine or an alien. Both teams have a commander that has a top down view, while the other players play in first person. The marine commander supplies the marines with ammo, health packs, weapons , etc and can put infrastructures as an armory, a tech machine thing, "generators", etc. While the aliens commander puts dow pods that create infestation ( that is nescessary to build aliens things ) and other structures that inhance aliens stats ( for some ). I tried to describe the better I could but you should look it up on Youtube to have a better look at what it really is.

Tho for the sake of game reviewing purposes I will give more intel.First pricewise you can't let this♥♥♥♥♥♥fool you, just because it's cheap doesn't mean it sucks, if the graphics suck it is because your graphics card sucks. Du it! or Kick starter it! and yea this game is the♥♥♥♥♥♥ Why else is it the♥♥♥♥♥♥ Let's see you can play as the aliens, wall run, ceiling run, and totally creep more agile like than the spy in TF2, or ninja in Warframe. The player count for the large maps is 16 vs 16 amazeballs. Matches last usually 10-15 mins good quick decisive doesn't take too much tyme. I like it. number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 4, 2016
												This is an excellent team based shooter, with marines vs. aliens, trying to kill each other's base. Add to that, each team has a commander that sees the map from overhead and uses team resources to build structures to aid this team, while directing his team to work together to grab objectives.The interaction between the commander and his team works very well and the majority of the community are actually nice, helpful people. There are a lot of variation in marine weapons and equipment and alien creatures but for new players this also means a bit steeper learning curve than usual for a shooter. Luckily, there's a tutorial, ingame hints and a single player sandbox mode with or without bots to help getting started. Also there are rookie servers for new players so you won't get completely stomped by veterans.If you like the idea of having to defend a dark, creepy corridor with your fellow marines against vicious aliens charging with more teeth than you can count, assaulting a nasty alien hive with grenade launchers, mechsuits and jet packs, sneak around the ceiling only to jump down and bite the head off an unsuspecting marine or charging a group of panicking marines with a massive dinosaur sized alien, this game won't let you down.Go get it. Now. The hive mind commands it.

												Every team combats in a online arena fighting for resources and, ultimately, to wipe the enemy team out. However, not everybody fights with guns and bombs: one player per team will be playing a strategic game, as the commander, leading their team to victory (or defeat).Not an easy game, and for this reason one of the best games out there of the category. number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 10, 2015
												It's a good blend of RTS and FPS elements, it feels like Aliens vs. Predator 2010 (The game, not the movies) and a good RTS like Command and Conquer (Also, screw you EA Games) had a baby and this was the result.  The game can be buggy and the Skulk (alien that bites you and runs on walls/ceilings) has an issue where the camera still is facing towards the ground (Even when you're sideways) and hard to stay on walls without a decent transition from surfaces and a lack of "Cling" to walls, but the biggest issue is the game is a hidden gem, as a multiplayer exclusive game.  So finding matches with decent connections can be trying at times.  However the game makes up for this with good squad combat, Alien agility, both factions playing completely differently including commanders or "Queens"A major thing to note is DO. NOT. Play. Commander or queens if you're just starting, they have a rediculously steep learning curve compaired to being on the ground.  If you do want to be commander, ensure you have a mic. and your team knows you're new to it as you need to be able to hear a soldier say "Drop extractor at hub" and know exactly where to go and what to do.  Generally vets are happy to help new people out and will be a nice guide, giving you build ideas and such. Overall it's worth a shot, and worst case scenario you can get your own server and play with a bunch of friends, although if you're like me and have no friends you're stuck on pubs, but always worth a shot.  It's also got a fair ammount of mods to set the mood!

Posted: December 12, 2013
												Natural selection 2 is great fun, coupled with strategy that makes the game something completely unique, having top down commander view and first person view the way it does is something I seldom see in games and I enjoy every second of it, the game itself is easy to learn but hard to master with all of the varying weapons and classes there is alot to love. the environments are detailed and entertaining as well and the mechanics just work. number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 4, 2015
												This game is a great mod dating back to the rise of DOD and CS. The concept is simple, combine RTS with FPS in a way that allows for skill and teamwork to be integrated into the game. Granted all games develop dogma over time, and this one is not different, non the less, there is much about this game that is worth while. It's reintroduction under the new half life 2 engine makes for a stunning acceleration of cybergaming. The artistiry and graphical display as well as game design and team balancing that the game designers have put into this game is remarable. The use of a voice  program embeded into the game is a nice side feature so you don't have to rent a teamspeak server or some such. In general it is a stylish game, with hip art, a sleak premis and plenty of fun.

Overall it's worth a shot, and worst case scenario you can get your own server and play with a bunch of friends, although if you're like me and have no friends you're stuck on pubs, but always worth a shot.  It's also got a fair ammount of mods to set the mood!

content:
Posted: July 9, 2014
 4/10 It is with no small amount of regret that I post this review. It is rare that such an interesting premise is presented for a mutliplayer game. The objective is to protect a ship from alien attackers or to infest the ship depending on the side you play (marines or aliens). There seems to be some good elements of gameplay and some varied and iteresting maps.There is a strategy element too this game as well where both sides have a "comander" who sees the whole maps and issues orders. Naturally this game seemed appealing.Unfortunately it is, as yet, unfinished. Load times alone make this game almost unplayable and the virtually non-existent multiplayer community make finding a game server with enough people a real challenge.When it is finished, and if it had greater support and a better reception it could become the next multiplayer game on the PC. The premise and the unique gameplay ought to be enough to interest people enough to purchase while it is still in the testing phase of development. It does not come cheap however and is not honestly worth the investment yet. Would I recomend this game?  Yes and no. Yes becasue it is an interesting and unique experience. No because it has no real multiplayer community which it desperately needs and at the moment load times make it almost unplayable.
