content:
Posted: June 29, 2015
												So here's the story: Got super excited when I found an Aliens VS Humans game(been looking for a tactical one like this for a LONG time), so I bought it for 10 USD.Started it up after installing: takes about 10 minutes to start up--and that's just the loading screen. No joke. I'm thinking, "Oh, maybe it just needs to load the files for the first time." Yeah I was wrong.Get to the menu, and I'm getting 7 FPS. Why? I've got over the system requirements and I'm running 7 FPS on medium settings, wth? Turn all the settings down to low, 720p resolution: get 15 FPS.Go to server browser and see if it's any better(by that I mean maybe it'll run faster in game). Find a server, try to connect to it. It's not full, and it's not connecting. Thought maybe a lot of stuff was happening in the server so it needed to process and load it all; nope. Wait about 5 mins and I close it out. Go to another server and try to connect, nope, after 5 mins again, I'm stuck on the dang loading screen.Finally decide to try the quick game option, and asks me if I want a tutorial. Hadn't ever played, so I clicked yes. And it takes around 10 mins to load...AGAIN. After it loads it's running 17 FPS(btw I have my Steam settings so I can see my FPS in game)...on lowest settings. My gosh...talk about not being optimized. So I start to hear the narrator and this is what immediately comes to mind after he's done speaking:'Background noise in the recording, you can hear the click to stop the audio from recording at the end, and there's a lot of static and it ends like it cut off; because there's not background noise in the game.' Can't believe that was the final audio recording for that, I have audacity(a free audio recording/editing program) with a $40 headset that sounds 10x better than this. I record it, if there's background noise I remove it ENTIRELY, and I have a cardboard box for my "professional" recording. Like really, this is the best you get when you release the game? That's one of the worst audio recordings I've ever heard in a game, it's rushed; unfinished and could have of been better made if you took your time.Enough about the audio rant, next, it tells me to build an armory, then kill some enemies. I start shooting the enemy(let's just call it an alien rat, first glance that's what I thought it was), and guess what happens? I drop half of my 17 FPS while fighting. I don't know why. I go back into my graphics settings after killing the alien rat and make sure everything is down, and turn the resolution down to the lowest. I decide to see what would happen if I turn up the quality on some things, because in some games it happens to run faster on higher settings; don't ask why, but they do. Anyways I literally JUST click the little arrow so that the texture quality is medium, and what happens next? Drop half of my 17 FPS again?, no. Increased FPS?, no. All of the dang HUD disappears off my screen. Nothing at all. No text for the settings menu, and no HUD whatsoever in game. Wth? I click the left arrow(arrow that decreases the quality) on the button-area I had clicked, and nothing happens. I hit apply: nothing. Not a single text is on my screen. Empty rectangles and empty boxes. I proceed to close out the menu and reopen it to see if it was glitched for a second. *sigh*...This keeps getting better and better, doesn't it? After I close the menu again my game freezes...comepletely freezes. It's sound is looping and locking at a certain point(that indicating it's completely frozen), I open task manager to close the process...and I don't see it. Because of course, the stupid application is covering my desktop and I'm blind to everything there. I tried for 3 minutes to get the stupid task manager to work, finally I found an option where I can "move" it by right clicking on its icon on the Windows bar. Move it over to my second monitor, and close out the application.TL;DR: Game froze, HUD disappeared, terribly optimized, bad experience. Had high hopes that I could play this but NOPE! I'm also REALLY ticked off that I'm above the recommended requirements, and that the requirements lied to us. I should be able to get a solid 30 FPS on min requirements on the lowest settings AT LEAST. NOPE! Bad game, uninstalling and not playing again.

content:
Posted: January 28, 2016
												This is a game I'd really like to like. I enjoyed the original mod, and I'm a big supporter of the idea of asymmetric gameplay in multiplayer FPS. Unfortunately, the netcode for this game is god-awful in anything but LAN play. You frequently have situations as an alien where you're sitting behind a wall, or a box---not in combat and you find yourself suddenly a corpse. You hear and see maybe 10 gunshots after the fact hitting your body. (happens with as low as 20-40 ping, with a decent server) It sounds like the beginning of a Kafka novel rather than any sort of fun. In combat, as an alien (but also happens -admittedly not as frequently- as the slower Marines) it seems as if you've been afflicted by some sort of invisible alien centipede tail trailing seconds behind that your enemy can shoot to kill you despite you already being safe and well away on your screen. It's strange that players find public-competitive gameplay even remotely enjoyable under these circumstances.gameplay-8/10graphics-7/10netcode written by australian lowlands gorilla-1/10

number of helpful: 5 of 9 people (56%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 19, 2014
												A standalone sequel a great Half-Life 1 mod, Natural Selection 2 is a triumph, and it's actually a bit amazing it exists at all. The game is an assymetical team based first person shooter, with one player on each team acting as its commander and playing the game like a traditional real time strategy game. The Human Marine side is fairly standard FPS fare (though still incredibly fun), while the Aliens play very uniquely, with different species to mutate into, and a whole host of bizarre abilities to unlock.The game runs on its own graphics engine, which looks incredible, and has been gradually optimized over the years so the initial limitations on running the game well seem to be largely resolved. The art and sound design of the maps give off an amazing industrial sci-fi vibe; this is a far more faithful game to the movie Aliens, which the game freely draws inspiration from, than the dreadful Colonial Marines cash-in.|My only criticism, aside from the occassional crash and perfomance issues, is that the game can be difficult to jump into and understand what is going on, what you need to do, and even what your role is, even as a basic Marine grunt. It's particularly difficult if you choose to play as the commander, though once you figure out some good strategies and tactics, have a solid skilled team that obeys orders, and you learn to effectively communicate, it can be the most rewarding way to play. It's also important to know that there is a dedicated fanbase of competitive players who take NS2 a bit seriously, so if that is not what you are looking for, make sure to only visit the casual servers for a while (the servers tend to helpfully label themselves as such).Recommended for those who like team based shooters, those with unique and assymetrical combat, sci-fi fans, and even strategy fans. If one or more of those things describes you, this game is worth it, even at full retail.

content:
Posted: February 13
												I'm not gonna lie, this game was fantastic, and when it was I got about 50 hours of fun out of it making it well worth the purchase, but now one downside is basically killing it. Lack of public servers to play on and people to play with.Back when this game started out, it was awesome, you could always find a server to play on that was populated with a bunch of people (I believe there were even some official servers, what ever happened to those?), back in those days anyone could enjoy this game for all it's worth.Now, my server browser can hardly find any servers most of the time, I'm lucky if it finds 3 within my ping range (which I set to a generous 100ms, don't want much higher than that in a shooter do we?), and I need to be lucky twice because chances are these servers are either full or empty,It happens that you find a good server to play on and you can play and play for hours with lots of people and have loads of fun, but you can't just pick up the game and play with the state of things being like this. I could always use the 'play now' featurewhich automatically finds a server for you but this would mean playing with♥♥♥♥♥♥latency and that dampens the fun quite a bit.Besides this glaring issue, tha the game basically feels like it's dying... The game is actually amazing, it's one of the most fun shooters I've ever played. There are two teams, Aliens and (space)Marines one player on each team has to be the commander, for this player the game is an RTS game, their job is to build bases and oversee and direct the rest of the players on their team to victory, the rest of the players are either marines or aliens, playing as marines and playing as aliens is a very different experience (no matter if you're the commander or a regular player)For the commander, the difference is of course the types of structures available and the pre-requisites for these structures to work. For marines a power generator needs to be built and kept online for structures in a room to operate, for Aliens cysts need to be built in the room to spread 'infestation' around it in order for you to be able to build in it. An alien commander can build without the help of his teammates as long as his teammates secure locations and keep the enemies out (or just busy), meanwhile the Marine commander needs other players to build his structures for him and has to order them to build for him. He can later build bots to do this for him but they are slow moving and come at a price.As for the infantry of both teams, the marines evolve by upgrading their weapons for example by buying shotguns or flamethrowers, later in the game their most elite technology is the exosuit, works kinda like the ones in the matrix.Aliens have a much more complex progression, aliens evolve by actually evolving, they all start as a 'skulk' which is the basic footsoldier which runs around and bites people's heels, from there they can turn into a gorge (support unit that can help the commander build and heal other units), a lerk (a pterodactyl with ranged attacks), Fade which is a humanoid stealth assassination unit that can deal lots of damage but only from melee range, and finally Onos to compete with the exosuit (it's basically a Triceratops that runs around and bashes things real violently).And that's about it, most of the game will be fought to control resource extraction points and base locations until one team manages to take over all the base locations exterminating all the opposing team's command centers/hives, both teams start with one command center/hive, they can build more in specific areas on the map and they have to contest each other for these areas. Once built, even if you lose your starting base you still haven't lost because you can run over to your alternate base and retake command from there.This game seamlessly blends strategy and tactics in a unique way, and I really really wish I could give it a thumbs up because of how great the game itself is, but no matter how great the game is, it doesn't really matter much if I can't really play it unless I have a private server and about 20 friends to join me. When you're hosting a server, you're lucky to get players. When you're playing, you're lucky to find a server, it's a hellish loop that no one enjoys. But I do sincerely hope that the developers will not give up on this game, find a solution to this problem before you make Natural Selection 3, and I will definitely buy that one too. If they are indeed developing Natural Selection 3 anytime soon then I hope they will also make commanding easier to do, the micro-management needed to command well in this game is nuts.

												Good game, bad community. It's really that simple. A competitive fps is only as good as its community, and this is amongst the worst I've ever encountered.Edit: This is one of the greatest, if not the greatest competitive fps I've ever played, so I don't want this review to sound so negative. number of helpful: 12 of 23 people (52%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 31, 2014
												I'm afraid I'll have to throw my lot in with the Nays this time. Fans of the first installment might find something here to scratch an old itch, but unfortunately the satisfying elements have all been rendered down and reimagined into a thin gruel in the name of having a saleable second entry. Useless gameplay features have been added for no apparent reason, such as the power node system. The Alien tech tree has been completely overhauled, and brings you an alien commander, which has gone through varying degrees of uselessness and boring gameplay over the various patches. Relocating the marine base is a thing of the past, as you now have tech points to capture that unlock parts of the tech tree. Gone are the days of the heavy/welder train, the OC farms outside 'rine spawn, trying to siege a hive before xeno gets unlocked...There is some fun to be had here, for sure. Newer comers to the genre will doubtless find the commander mechanic new and engaging, and the differences between the aliens and marines is a fresh breath of air in the standard rote of FPS gameplay. The game looks sharp, and running on walls and cielings as an alien is second to none. Unfortunately with the glaring technical issues NS2 launched with, by the time the game was playable, there was no one left to play it with. Pick this game up on sale if you're interested - $25 is too steep by half.

Now a game that only ever has a few hundred people playing it now has a fairly large percentage of its player base sequested off of the main server list. And if the devs will blatently surpress one community, who knows what they'll do to the next bunch of servers that they decide they don't like.

content:
Posted: December 3, 2013
												i really can't believe the devs behind this game actually made this work. I mean, a RTS + FPS combined into one game is kinda hard.however, this game suffers from very poor performance issues, i can only play this game with an acceptable fps if I turn everything down to absolute minimum setting (i5 2500k, 560ti). The performance increased after a recent patch but still is not as good as I'd like it to be.Another problem with this game is the shooting mechanic. Sustained firing slows down your character significantly which really is not fair considering how fast the aliens move in this game. They also had a problem with mouse acceleration but it was complete removed with a recent patch and now aiming is A LOT better, this really is a big plus for me.The problem with a RTS style "commander" system is that it's really hard (in pubs at least) to find a competent player to play the commander role who has really good situational awareness to drop ammo/medkit for players on the team while at the same time good at knowing when and what to upgrade (armor, guns).The best part about this game is probably the developer team behind it. They are really invested in the game, always try their best to talk to and listen to the community and they actually play the game in their free time with the community lol. Basically you get the feeling they really do care about it and want this game to succeed.Overall I recommand this game, but just keep in  mind that it's not everyday you meet a capable "commander" who can guide your team to a win. So don't be all mad when you loose, it's normal lol.Edit: oh i hope this game becomes a more popular professional competitive game like CS. because this really is a very team-oriented competitive game.

												Natural Selection 2 is the best human vs monster game since left 4 dead 2. Got on sale for under $2. What a steal,almost feel like i should of paid more. Sunit

												Natural Selection 2 is so far my best experience concerning multiplayer games. Basically it combines strategy and ego shooter in one exiting game. In average a game lasts between 5 and 60 min and especially good teamplay is required. After about 300 hours of fun, I really recommend this game to all gamers looking for a top class ground-breaking and fun teamplay-RTS-Shooter. Finally I want to point out the great philosophy of the independent developer/community unknown worlds entertainment. I mean 20 bugs and frequent updates for free and everyone? Awesome.So ... have fun.Greetings and always remember: rage-quitting is a crime! ;)

content:
Posted: November 25, 2016
												This game is the true definition of "hidden gem". I dare say that NS2 just may be one of the best FPS/RTS I have ever played. And trust me, I played a lot of them.Imagine playing a really awesome skill- and team-based FPS like Team Fortress 2, while at the same time 1 player in your team plays as a "commander", basically transforming his game into Starcraft, but instead of controlling marines and zerlings, he gives orders to players. And through teamwork, tactics and cooperation, your team must destroy the opponents base. This is what this game is all about. I have no idea if people still play NS2 (I used to play it long ago), but if they do, then definitely buy this game. It's an awesome and unique experience you will never forget.

content:
Posted: December 18, 2013
												Okay. Like the Alien Trilogy? Like actual teamwork. Want an actually friendly community? Like the sound of xenomorphic teeth ripping through space marine armor? Like feeling like like the STATE OF THE BADASS ART? GET THIS GAME.Down to its core, NS2 is a game of teamwork. Two asymetrical teams fight to the death for the future of their species. This isn't an average FPS. Both teams, the human Frontiersman and the alien Kharaa, have radical differences in playstyle, but also some striking similarities. The largest similarity, is the presesne of a player acting as a commander for the team. Being a commander compared to being a soldier or a skulk on the front lines is radically different as well. You have to act as the coordinator of your team. You are responsible for keeping an eye on the map, and telling your teammates what needs to be done. NS2 is like an armsrace, where both teams compete to outdamage, outgrow, and eventually overwhelm the other. Playing as a marine, you experience an almost completely different game than as an alien. And because each and every game populated by soley players, no two games are alike. NS2 is not a "spunk-gargle-weewee 360 noscope FPS". NS2 is a game of tactics.Natural Selection looks beautiful. The sci-fi maps, the Darwinism-on-steroids aesthetics of the Kharaa, the sounds, the effects... These all give NS2 this amazing and unique appearance. I have felt true fear when the aliens cut the lights and forced me to engage them in near pitch dark. I have felt the pride swell at being a part of a sucessful push into enemy territory. I have felt the joys of victory, the humility of defeat, and also respect for the enemy team when they manage to outmaneouver us.The community of Natural Selection 2 is generally friendly and helpful. While there might be a few bad examples here and there, the players are consistantly nice. So long as you're not a caustic individual, you find the community to be one of the strongest aspects of this game.Get this game. As a fan of the Alien series, this is the game I never recieved. As a fan of deeper games, NS2 has more depth than any probably any other online shooter out there. Thats why I recommend this game. Because this was the kind of game I was always looking for.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 7, 2014
												If you like RTS+FPS combinations (I have a fond memory of Savage, the first game it this kind I played), Natural Selection 2 is a very good one. The races are very distinct (marines are a bit weaker but easier to learn, aliens are a bit stronger but harder to control), the gameplays have reasonable length, the graphics are great, there's enough people playing it, you can drop in/drop out anytime, there is quite a depth in the overall strategy. Of course, this is game is very dependent on the commander skill. But you can even eject the commander from his seat, if you're not satisfied with him.If you start playing this game, definitely look into the Guides section on Steam and read the most popular guides and/or watch some introduction videos. Even if you're not the commander, you're still playing a strategy, and you should know what your team priorities are. If you do read the guides, you'll enjoy the game more, because you'll have better understanding what's going on in there. And of course, you'll also possibly survive longer. Also, communication is the key in this game. Always listen to what others are saying on the team voice chat, and if possible, connect a microphone and talk to them as well.The developers are still maintaining this game, balancing it, adding features. They interact with the community a lot. Recommended.

content:
Posted: January 6, 2015
												Natural Selection 2 is the game for you, if you like fast paced intuitive competitive FPS with added RTS elements and heavy tactical touch to a game ! It has a fairly steep learning curve, but the game experience makes up for it !It runs pretty smoothly now, tho it's loading time is somewhat long.The two sides (alien vs marine) plays completely different, each having it's own unique gameplay.Game time varies from 5 min to 60 min, depends on the teams.It can - at times - be pretty one sided, which, if you endure, may result in the next match being the best match you've ever played yet !The community is really friendly, and they patiently explain stuff if you're not familiar with the game ! 8/10 (lacks unit variety and customization - but you have mods for this !)

content:
Posted: January 17, 2015
												This is not your average shooter. You don't sit in hallways and snipe, you don't lurk in corners or vents (unless you're an alien :D ), and you really can't lone wolf effectively. The different sides, alien and marines, require different mindsets and strategies to win. You normally can't just run as a solo skulk or marine and win. The map designs are amazing and the atmosphere is very impressive. There are specific areas of each map that one side will excel at using and trying to take one of those areas as the other side is usually costly. The maps are also unique in layout and space use. Not every map is a tiny cluster**** or a giant open arena. The game and its "classes" require a bit of learning. It isn't just who can shoot fastest or get kills most effectively. There is far more going on and the strategy side of commander mode can rapidly change the outcome of a battle. The hardest part was getting used to commander mode. I am a fan of the RTS style game but this was a whole new level of awesome. Players following orders you gave and seeing your upgrades or buildings change the tide is downright exciting. I do have some problems with game optimization and mechanics but its nothing to cry about. TL;DR If you enjoy teamwork, strategic gameplay, and general awesomeness this is a fine game. It is absolutely worth the buy and worth practicing. It can be tough to learn and may even not be enjoyable at first. This is until you get some practice in and learn the ropes. FInd a newbie friendly server (marked on server browser) and get started!

												It's fun but extremely challenging. If you want to play a game that will really challenge your ability to work as a team and be a better player, this is the game for you.Sadly, the sharp and very early learning curve combined with the low-population have led this game to fall apart and die. It's slowly fading out of existence, which is terrible considering how great this game really is.Edit 11/27/2016:The community is slowly growing with new players thanks to the free weekends but it still has more to go if it wants to continue to stay alive. The community needs to be less toxic and focus more on helping new players. With such a wide skill difference between experienced players and newbies, it's going to be a tough road to break through to becoming popular. I don't think this game will ever really become popular again though, sadly. Updated for badge!

												Wow.. Natural Selection 2 is one of the best gaming experiences I've had. This is not an easy game to get into right away, but it's a blast to play from the start and it's a blast to play when you've pumped many hours into it. The community is fun and active and will be for years ahead. Most people are helpful and kind, lending help to new players.This is a game for anyone to get into in my opinion. Mics help, but aren't required, but you DO need to listen to your teammates/com  to work together. Once you get into the flow of things, it can become a bit too addicting.Blasting aliens hecticly and chomping humans to death is delivered with beautiful level design, stunning attention to detail, andactive dev patches, new weapons, etc. Buy it n try it.

content:
Posted: November 22, 2015
												Now that I have a rig that can properly handle NS2, I think it's finally time for a review.This game is incredible. I've been playing since NS1 but the devs completely outdid themselves with 2.NS2 is extremely immersive and incredibly exciting. Strategy and teamwork are required and winning is very rewarding as a result. The graphics are rich, even on low settings and that only adds to how easily one can get zoned right in while playing. For an FPS that features two completely unique teams, the game is incredibly balanced. The devs did a bafflingly amazing job at that.Yes the game has a learning curve but the way it works makes perfect sense. It's not easy at first. As for how the community responds to inexperienced players, I'm terrible but I personally have not witnessed or experience any abuse beyond somone saying, for example, "What the heck are you doing? Don't do that, this is where you're supposed to go or what you're supposed to do. Use this." That's standard for any game that involves constant strategy.The game currently has a small community but almost all of the servers with players in them are either full or nearly full, so you'll always find a good game.If you have not played Natural Selection and are even just slightly considering this game, get it. If you enjoy FPS and/or strategy, get it. If you enjoy defending humanity against aliens or ripping humans apart with claws and jaws, get it. If you enjoy mech suits and jetpacks, get it. If you enjoy flying about and gassing humans, get it. If you are a gamer who takes pride in playing a wide variety of games, this is essential.If you already have this game and  are not playing it, you probably forgot how amazing it is, so play it. And why are you here reading this in the first place?

content:
Posted: February 25, 2016
												As someone who has dumped well over 1000 hours on Natural Selection 1, this game is on life support.Its a great game that just has too many bad business decisions about it all around. The major crux in this game is making NS2 Combat as a Standalone buy seperately, just for a different game mode that was VERY popular in the NS1 days.As such, thanks to this decision, NS Combat is like 8 or 9 bucks for a completely dead mode. Which sucks since Combat was a lot of high intensity fun! Even if Combat wasnt the main draw of NS, it kept a lot of players interested in the game to extend the lifespan of NS1 much longer than it should have as a mod.The lack of respect shown from Unknown Worlds has shown to this great game is staggering. Opening up a skin store and making a exclusive marine weapon to buyers is another ♥♥♥♥♥♥ move to reward your longtime players.That aside, this is a very fun team based game. I just wish that this could be absurdly popular as the NS1 days were. All love to making a great game better, but with no microtransactions.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 18, 2016
												NS2 is fantastic as a game, but it requires commitment and has a steep learning curve. If you're willing to put the time into getting over that initial difficulty barrier, you'll be rewarded with a very deep and strategic game.The community is waning, but still present. This is a small game, make no mistake.The last warning is performance. MAKE SURE YOUR MACHINE CAN RUN THIS GAME. NS2 is poorly optimized and very CPU hungry. Do your homework, run your hardware comparisons.Honestly, I run this game in 800x600 resolution in order to get 30fps and above and I still enjoy it. Assuming performance isn't an issue, I would still recommend it. There's always something to do, you never feel unimportant (even if you can't aim and have to play support, it's still rewarding), it's actively under development and the devteam is focusing on making the game more newbie friendly and improving player retention.

Play if you are a an awesome team player, who listens to more experienced people because you know you are rubbish when first starting off in the game, like every one was at one point in their NS2 "career". DO NOT PLAY if you want a casual, fun and relaxing game.

content:

												Great concept that can provide brief moments of joy when you successfully execute a clever maneuver especially if you have a good commander, which is a single player that controls the overview map and places base structures and markers to coordinate your team.Unfortunately the weapons all have the same weightless peashooter feeling (whether your chomping with teeth, shooting an assault rifle or going full tilt with a chaingun it all just feels "meh") and the maps are big but can be fairly confusing because each area looks mostly the same. There is also a learning curve that isn't quite worth the effort to me for those occasional spurts of brilliant fun. However, If you have a dedicated group of a half dozen online friends and you're looking for a unique multiplayer experience this could be very rewarding.

content:
Posted: March 28, 2015
												The following is a quick overview of Natural Selection 2 for a full review please check out my website at - {LINK REMOVED}http://ausiejamster.wix.com/ausiesgamingzone#!natural-selection-2/cj2tNatural Selection 2 is a first-person shooter combined with a real time strategy game, resulting in the ultimate competitive experience. The game can contain any number of players completely based on the number of players the server can handle, however, in tournament events they appear to use twelve players per games while the average server is around sixteen to twenty players per game. Natural Selection 2 is almost completely an online experience but does offer an offline training mode to help new players understand the game without having to figure out the basics in a competitive environment. The game was developed by Unknown Worlds Entertainment using the Spark source engine (which was also developed by Unknown Worlds Entertainment). Natural Selection 2 was released to the public as open source code to help players develop modifications much easier. By the game's title its pretty obvious that Natural Selection 2 is the second game of the Natural Selection series the first of which was one of the ten most played Half-Life modifications but was never released as a standalone. Unfortunately it is only available on PC but is purchasable on steam. The graphics aren't really top tier but aren't terrible either, they just need a little more work so they stand out a little more. The in game experience of Natural Selection 2 doesn't actually offer any music and the SFX are a little poor in some places. The designers of Naturals Selection 2 decided that they shouldn't really mess around with a storyline, instead allow the player to just jump straight into the game itself and as a result the game has little to know story line at all. The game is however, updated quite regularly and does offer some DLCs that allows the player to customise the texture of the in game characters for a small price. The options in this game are also pretty impressive with the ability to not only change video and audio options but also proformance settings and experimental proformance settings as well. The gameplay is very intense within the game forcing the player to practise strategy, game knowledge and mechanical skill to master the game making repetitiveness not really a factor. The competitive side is still growing within esports and should be a very impressive once it has. Overall I gave the game a 7.7/10 final rating as the game play, options and content just make the game. The audio is really lacking and the graphics aren't top tier either, but with updates this could really improve.

content:
Posted: January 14, 2014
												I did find this game to be fun for a while, despite constantly dieing. I was intrigued about its unique gameplay style and its focus on resources and upgrades. But as I played I always felt that the sides weren't properly balanced. After bouncing from one explanation to the next I've finnally decided that the biggest problem this game has (despite the lack of commanders that people won't kick out) is the skill cap imbalances between the sides. First there is an initial skill wall that players need to get used to, so they can kill anything on the other team; but worst of all is that the best players can do so spectacularly well that the entire other team can deprive these "pros" of their teams recourses and still be out matched. In fact they can do so well with basic equipment and aliens that they won't need any or many other upgrades.In short Natural selection hasn't removed enough of the skill disparity between players to keep induvidual skill from surpasing and making team collaboration, and the need to control resources.Its like the sniper in team fortress 2, Valve made it so you can't crit unless scoped for a headshot, and the damge delt is also proportionate to the time the sniper has spent scoped. Valve went to great lengths to keep induvidual skill from surpassing team collaboration. Something Natural Selection 2 needs to improve on.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 7, 2014
												If you like RTS+FPS combinations (I have a fond memory of Savage, the first game it this kind I played), Natural Selection 2 is a very good one. The races are very distinct (marines are a bit weaker but easier to learn, aliens are a bit stronger but harder to control), the gameplays have reasonable length, the graphics are great, there's enough people playing it, you can drop in/drop out anytime, there is quite a depth in the overall strategy. Of course, this is game is very dependent on the commander skill. But you can even eject the commander from his seat, if you're not satisfied with him.If you start playing this game, definitely look into the Guides section on Steam and read the most popular guides and/or watch some introduction videos. Even if you're not the commander, you're still playing a strategy, and you should know what your team priorities are. If you do read the guides, you'll enjoy the game more, because you'll have better understanding what's going on in there. And of course, you'll also possibly survive longer. Also, communication is the key in this game. Always listen to what others are saying on the team voice chat, and if possible, connect a microphone and talk to them as well.The developers are still maintaining this game, balancing it, adding features. They interact with the community a lot. Recommended.

												Natural Selection 2 is the game for you, if you like fast paced intuitive competitive FPS with added RTS elements and heavy tactical touch to a game ! It has a fairly steep learning curve, but the game experience makes up for it !It runs pretty smoothly now, tho it's loading time is somewhat long.The two sides (alien vs marine) plays completely different, each having it's own unique gameplay.Game time varies from 5 min to 60 min, depends on the teams.It can - at times - be pretty one sided, which, if you endure, may result in the next match being the best match you've ever played yet !The community is really friendly, and they patiently explain stuff if you're not familiar with the game ! 8/10 (lacks unit variety and customization - but you have mods for this !)

content:
Posted: November 4, 2014
												I don't care for the game. Every server I've ever been to are filled with idle players in the team selection area. The commanders in the RTS part of the game don't ever seem capable of their role. The players per team balancing is all messed up, you often fight against a much larger team.The Marines team's weapons feel extremely weak, and there aren't many of them. You usually end up emptying multiple magazines into a single enemy only to die during a reload. Feels like it needs serious rebalancing. Respawn is pretty fast because what seems to be an advanced 3D printer spits out marines non stop. I can't find any reason at all to upgrade anything, as most items are equally useless. The aliens usually enjoy spawn camping rather than destroying your base (which they are always in). I've never actually made it inside the aliens' base as a marine before.The Aliens team usually consists of playing as the weakest alien for about 20 minutes, running straight into groups of marines and jumping up and down while trying to bite them. Hit detection for the aliens seems really terrible, can never seem to hit anything. Then, once you've finally gotten enough points you can evolve into a new type of alien. The catch is, if you die, you respawn as the weakest alien, lose all your points you invested into the alien you died as, and have find a way to get enough points before you can evolve into something again. I think the commanders can increase the points you generate over time somehow, though like I said most commanders aren't capable of assisting the team. Players that pick the support alien type usually don't support, instead they prefer to slide on their bellies like penguins and fly into the middle of battles. Certain players that are actually good usually pick Fade within 5 minutes somehow and never die.The sounds were decent, the gameplay was a good idea, just didn't work too well, the community wasn't impressive- no one ever seems to work together, and when they do they get killed by a lone person on the other team anyway. Balancing didn't feel right. The load times are insane, you have to wait for about 5 minutes just to join a server, something about shading and caches and what not. Shading wasn't good, there are objects in the world that completely lack shadows. Graphics were okay, nothing special, but the poor performance would suggest otherwise. The bot AI is stupid, though it is a multiplayer game, and it probably wasn't intended to be a big point in the game.Overall I can't suggest the game. Maybe a 4/10, there are worse games, but there are certainly better.

content:
Posted: February 25, 2016
												As someone who has dumped well over 1000 hours on Natural Selection 1, this game is on life support.Its a great game that just has too many bad business decisions about it all around. The major crux in this game is making NS2 Combat as a Standalone buy seperately, just for a different game mode that was VERY popular in the NS1 days.As such, thanks to this decision, NS Combat is like 8 or 9 bucks for a completely dead mode. Which sucks since Combat was a lot of high intensity fun! Even if Combat wasnt the main draw of NS, it kept a lot of players interested in the game to extend the lifespan of NS1 much longer than it should have as a mod.The lack of respect shown from Unknown Worlds has shown to this great game is staggering. Opening up a skin store and making a exclusive marine weapon to buyers is another ♥♥♥♥♥♥ move to reward your longtime players.That aside, this is a very fun team based game. I just wish that this could be absurdly popular as the NS1 days were. All love to making a great game better, but with no microtransactions.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 18, 2016
												NS2 is fantastic as a game, but it requires commitment and has a steep learning curve. If you're willing to put the time into getting over that initial difficulty barrier, you'll be rewarded with a very deep and strategic game.The community is waning, but still present. This is a small game, make no mistake.The last warning is performance. MAKE SURE YOUR MACHINE CAN RUN THIS GAME. NS2 is poorly optimized and very CPU hungry. Do your homework, run your hardware comparisons.Honestly, I run this game in 800x600 resolution in order to get 30fps and above and I still enjoy it. Assuming performance isn't an issue, I would still recommend it. There's always something to do, you never feel unimportant (even if you can't aim and have to play support, it's still rewarding), it's actively under development and the devteam is focusing on making the game more newbie friendly and improving player retention.

												Probably one of the best FPS games I've played since 007!  Seriously, from Doom, Quake, and every Unreal series games, NS2 is the most challenging and satisfying of all.  Strategic elements, various classes and abilities, combined with traditional twitch skills, makes for a superb game that's hard to put down.  The competitive community is a serious one.  You're bound to develop many friendships with mature players, which makes this game even more worthwhile.  Highly Recommended!

number of helpful: 10 of 20 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 4, 2014
												I don't care for the game. Every server I've ever been to are filled with idle players in the team selection area. The commanders in the RTS part of the game don't ever seem capable of their role. The players per team balancing is all messed up, you often fight against a much larger team.The Marines team's weapons feel extremely weak, and there aren't many of them. You usually end up emptying multiple magazines into a single enemy only to die during a reload. Feels like it needs serious rebalancing. Respawn is pretty fast because what seems to be an advanced 3D printer spits out marines non stop. I can't find any reason at all to upgrade anything, as most items are equally useless. The aliens usually enjoy spawn camping rather than destroying your base (which they are always in). I've never actually made it inside the aliens' base as a marine before.The Aliens team usually consists of playing as the weakest alien for about 20 minutes, running straight into groups of marines and jumping up and down while trying to bite them. Hit detection for the aliens seems really terrible, can never seem to hit anything. Then, once you've finally gotten enough points you can evolve into a new type of alien. The catch is, if you die, you respawn as the weakest alien, lose all your points you invested into the alien you died as, and have find a way to get enough points before you can evolve into something again. I think the commanders can increase the points you generate over time somehow, though like I said most commanders aren't capable of assisting the team. Players that pick the support alien type usually don't support, instead they prefer to slide on their bellies like penguins and fly into the middle of battles. Certain players that are actually good usually pick Fade within 5 minutes somehow and never die.The sounds were decent, the gameplay was a good idea, just didn't work too well, the community wasn't impressive- no one ever seems to work together, and when they do they get killed by a lone person on the other team anyway. Balancing didn't feel right. The load times are insane, you have to wait for about 5 minutes just to join a server, something about shading and caches and what not. Shading wasn't good, there are objects in the world that completely lack shadows. Graphics were okay, nothing special, but the poor performance would suggest otherwise. The bot AI is stupid, though it is a multiplayer game, and it probably wasn't intended to be a big point in the game.Overall I can't suggest the game. Maybe a 4/10, there are worse games, but there are certainly better.

number of helpful: 4 of 8 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 30, 2014
												Unknown Worlds has ceased development after one and a half years and a half-million dollar "reinforcement" program (read: donations for an update).  There will also be new skins for sale for $6 soon!  A terrible example of greed and lack of vision.As a beta-tester, I can say that the game itself never got out of beta.  The balance changes that occurred consistently and without much consideration resulted in a game that was mostly unlearnable and never quite sure which side it would favor.  Additionally balance changes would alter between considering professional and casual gameplay.  Without a consistent direction the community is more insular and aggressive than the stereotypical FPS community, and while this aggression is not always outward or vulgar the players are prone to dramatic and violent changes in behaviour.  Don't do the wrong thing as a commander or player or there will be at least one person to let you have it.Originally a bunch of designers that knew each other in college, Unknown Worlds' expansion and solidification in San Francisco to launch Natural Selection 2 was a ploy to earn enough money and acclaim to work on other projects.  Amazingly video game companies did this for the last thirty years without sacrificing the games that made them successful, but these days customers do not matter to any business, even a successful small one.  The giant game company whose name denotes a violent winter storm supported the first iterations of two of their most prominent IPs for over ten years with patches, charging once after purchase for a single expansion pack.The Spark engine will ostensibly be re-used, but I sure won't be as a customer.

content:
Posted: May 11, 2016
												1.) review2.) advertisement1. review:first off... im very disappointed at the developers of this game for making many bad decisions way of planing the game (e.g. playing toturial in 2016) and... if they had planed better and acted sooner ns2 could have glory days even right now as the graphics are still VERY fresh compared to games of 2015 or even 2016despite all of that... this game is amazingly awesome for its unique gameplay, teamplay, and strategyplayits one of the most challanging games ever and not some brainless shooter gamefor everyone who will play this game for the first time... you will be utterly crushed and stomped >:)if that doesnt scare you and you take a hard challange you will have to spend quite some time tounderstand the strategy part of the game while fusing it with your tactical shooter skillsonce you have mastered the strategy and the tactical shooter skills you will be able to know what to do out on the fieldand even be able to tell your fellow teammates your well thought strategy while you are adepting to the fast changing situations! however... if you run brainlessly as a pro shooter and actually kill many enemies you might end up losing the game by giving away someones position and ruining their strategy which depends on winning the game ;)2. advertisement:if you want to look into the community i play you should open the server browser and click on the filter "all" then search for wooza's playground which has 42 playerslots + 4 spectator slots (46slots)there are many other wooza servers (luckily) wooza's community is very generous kind and helpful towards practically everyoneas example some of my friends were playing on his server and won random games (killing floor 2, risen 3,etc...) in the game although there has been a lot of drama if you want to check the unknown worlds entertainment forums...if you feel too much pressure on the vanilla game which has maxium 24 (12vs12) players (which isnt a lot and makes almost every player dependend on winning the game) just come by because your newbieness wont affect the team as much! the only thing it could affect is your computer's performance it can be kind of bad if you have a potato computer compared to the vanilla game servers

number of helpful: 6 of 12 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 6, 2016
												I bought this game two days after a friend of mine showed me a few screens of the alien-species (Kharaa) two or three years ago.I couldn't stop playing it for two weeks, it was something entirely new. Playing the marines was nothing like playing Counter Strike or similar games. You move much slower and can't crouch, just walk and run. You have to use a flashlight when the power nod in your area got destroyed and the weapons you can use are limited to a pistol, an axe, a...wielder(? healing-thing), a mashine gun, a shotgun, a flamethrower, a grenade launcher, mines and a few different types of grenades. On the other hand you can research jetpacks and Exos (those gigantic roboter suits). The beauty of this team are the many cool things you can build. Other than the armory (storage for weapons etc.) you can build sentry guns to defend your base against aliens or small tank-like mashines to attack the enemy.The aliens are my absoloute favorite. You can play as Skulk, Gorge, Lerk, Fade or Onos, everyone of those has their own pros and cons, but I prever the Skulk. I love hoding in dark corners, waiting for a stupid marine who walks around on his own and killing him before he even gets what's happening. At the beginning, it was quite hard to master the fast, wild movements of every alien (except for the onos...can't call that "fast"), I had to get the hang of it to actually harm any marines, but it didn't take much time. With the Gorge being able to build countless different structures to support his team, there are many tactical possibilities to finally destroy your enemy's commander station. Which brings me to the actual clue of the game: The need of a commander. Without a commander, the team can't research new structures and weapons (marines) or new abilitys and upgrades (aliens). Also, the commander is essential for a great teamplay. He coordinates attacks, can drop healing- or ammo-packs for marines and cysts for aliens, spreading the area controlled by them. Also, he's the one dropping ressource-gaining towes all over the map for both teams, so if you lost your commander and those get destroyed, you can't buy better weapons (marines) or evolve to higher creatures (aliens) anymore. A good commander brings you half-way to victory, but of course the other players actually listening is almost as important. The incredible high amount of tactics and teamplay won me over in minutes and I still love playing this game with friends or with random people on the servers. Only flaw is the training-mode. The bots (especially aliens) tend to get stuck in the ground or walls, leaving you alone to defend your base. It's a good way getting used to the commander-job, however, or getting the basics. I can only recommend this game with high praise, but you should be sure to have a computer that can take it. Before I got the hadware-upgrade, the game wasn't exactly fluent, even though I lowered the graphics. Now, it runs perfectly.-Nymuz

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 5, 2016
												Natural Selection 2 is the kind of game that we may never see the likes of again, its basically a top down strategy game, similar to "Warhammer 40k Dawn of War", except instead of AI moving around the map and building its players in a First Persom Perspective.The gameplay in this game is extremely competitive and a lot of strategy is involved so if you're looking for a casual experince you need to look somewhere else. Players in this game constantly use communication and all work as a team, this isn't your run-of-the-mill FPS, if you don't pull your weight people will yell at you and in some cases kick you. Battles can get extremely chaotic and its a lot of fun but the learning curve in this game is quite steep, when you start playing you will die, a lot. If you don't like strategy games and communication this game seriously isn't for you, I cannot stress enough how much team work and coordination is involved.

content:
Posted: May 19, 2016
												After initially giving a negative review, I was reached out to by some members of the community (thank you Wooza and WasabiOne) who urged me to give it another chance.And having done so, I can confidently say that with some reservations I CAN recommend this game.The game is very fun and my initial impression that the community was full of ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s has changed; it seems like I met most of the jerks right off the bat and since then I've played with some cool people.Another opinion that's changed is that after you become rookie, you can barely play anymore because there are so few active servers after the "Rookie only" servers. This is still true; however, it seems to me a shrinking problem which is nice. I haven't had as much trouble finding games as in my previous review.I was getting very frustrated with how often (after rookie only servers) I was constantly getting destroyed, but this too has gone away as the game mechanics (besides commanding) are pretty intuitive and with some patience and effort I no longer feel like a total idiot/scrub.Needless to say, my sinking disappointment after I left the rookie servers at how awful the game seemed is gone and I think I've found another game to play regularly! Woohoo!

content:
Posted: June 3, 2016
												Natural Selection never got the love it deserved in my opinion. The marine team is essentially what I've always wanted FPS games to be like in the multiplayer section. A commander has a birds-eye view and can order marines specifically [Giving you, as the player, side objectives that help the team]. In most games I would complain about the ability to full auto and have such small spread, but you NEED it, as the aliens have a lot of finesse. This is truly a team game, where a high kill count and low death score isn't as important as securing strategic locations and getting resource nodes for your commander.As Alien, it's a bit tricky. It's very easy to understand, but hard to master. This game often plays as a horror game, as good alien players often will ambush and surprise marine teams, making it hard to steady your aim. Onos has to be the most fun [In my opinion] to play, and let's even a noob who's willing to save up resources try out this behemoth of a xenomorph. Trust me, you won't regret at least trying this game.

content:
Posted: June 3, 2016
Product received for free
												Tremulous, Gloom and Natural Selection... Tbh its hard to choose which is the best out of the three.Gloom is a fast paced frag-based with variation in the damage system, Tremulous is fast paced as well and can be fun as hell but often camping simulator, Natural Selection sucks whenever one team starts to lose and if that is your team, because all the players joining mid-game always join the winning team, and NS2's heavy reliance on teamstrategy makes it difficult to carry the team. However I do enjoy aliens and commander isn't so bad. The game also heavily relies on the fact marines can pick up weapons from corpses. I can imagine how aweful humans are when they are no longer able to pick up their weapons.However as all three games go, they do have a gameplay trend: Human-biased with lots of players and alien-biased with little amount of players.Oh well who cares its still fun.

number of helpful: 6 of 12 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 16, 2016
												Do I have quite a bit of hours? Yes.So the question is: Why would I not recommend a game that I have spent so much time playing? It is simple. I have been playing on modded servers all the time. And those are now being killed by the devs. This game is not bad. Infact I love it's concept and with some mods it is just the game I spent my weekends playing as you can tell by the playtime. But the game is changing in a direction that I cannot support. It is going all out competitive where it feels like the devs are trying to kill the part of their community that consists of casual non-league gamers. While supposedly focusing on new players and player retention (as stated by themselves) the devs have painfully neglected and put off large parts of the existing playerbase. Especially the community that enjoys large servers or total conversion mods. When you see a server browser what is the first thing you do? Yes, sort by players. And then? Yes, join the top most that has room. Why is that? It is because you like playing a multiplayer game with a lot of other players and it is way more forgiving for a new player if there are more people that can compensate or help you learning the ropes. The devs think that this is ruining your fun as a new player. So they have hid all servers not fitting their dogmatic view on what a true NS2 server is. Leaving you to competitive low population servers by default unless you find the hidden quirks in the menus to unlock the other servers. This effectively kills the influx of new players to those modded servers denying them the upkeep and having those communities die a slow death.If you like spending hours watching tutorial videos and training on bot servers before you are fit to join an official server go ahead and buy it. You might like going all league and competitive. But if you are looking for a game to play once in a while look for something else, you will probably not enjoys this (anymore).

number of helpful: 16 of 32 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 6, 2016
												This is probably one of the best games ever made. A Unique blend of FPS and RTS. Two commanders preside over two very different teams for control of the map and its resources. The ultimate aim of course, to annihilate the enemy.The marines are the more traditional FPS team whilst the aliens offer a unique yet very cleverly designed play experience.Every round is different and the feeling of winning a hard-fought game or coming back from the brink of defeat with your team is one you rarely find in other games.There can be a steep learning curve initially, but find your feet on a Rookie only server and then join some quality communities and master the game, (Tactical Gamer and The Thirsty Onos are excellent choices).Above all I urge people to play and judge this game on its merits, not on any other factors or misleading reviews.

content:
Posted: March 26, 2016
												Fun game for a cheap price. Games can span anywhere from 10 minutes to 2 hours depending on how well the teams are balanced. Need to be strategic behind what you do in this game and it's not just a COD were you run around and shoot things. Requires communication with your commander who drops stuff for you and ensures upgrades were you are weak.The community is awesome and people are very friendly. If your a noob just simply say so and ask were you are needed. Why? Because players communicate and commanders normally will tell you were to go if your not sure. I ran into a few people who were simply trolls/a-holes and my hole team told him to @$ck off and nobody ever backed him up. He shortly left and I hope he uninstalled.The gameplay:Play as MARINES at first because it's the most familiar play smart and stick with your group/don't split up. Keep your distance from the aliens and move strategically and communicate with your commander. ALIENS are more of ambushing and simply harder to play the MARINES and the ALIENS rely on MARINES being a little to cocky and pushing bad spots.

content:
Posted: January 21, 2016
												A fantastic game with a good balance of tactic, shooter and strategy. if you want a deeper and more intensiv game than Battlefield or Call of Duty, this Game here is the best for you. i always found other shooter like cod too easy and too simple. go in, shoot others and don't care what your teammates do. the only goal is too achieve better skins for your weapons. i wanted a game with more teamplay and communication. NS2 gives you exactly that. you have to communicate with your team, you have to play in team. the requiered skill is very high. you cannot simply run around like in cod and kill everything. alone marines are dead marines. and if you have enough of shooting you can switch the teams and play aliens. a totally different playstyle.and the most important aspect in the game is the good combination of strategygame and shooter. only killing the enemy will not help you to win this game. you need a good commander that helps you captuering ressourcepoints. ressource is the money in the game. you need to capture the ressource points to unlock better weapons and armors in the fight. but don't think of premium users now. you can only unlock better weaopons for one round. there is no premium in this game. except of other skins you cannot get any other benefits for money.This game is a challenge to learn and you will die very often at the beginning. once again: This is NOT Cod or Battlefield. Don't expect to get in this game and kill everything alone. THe first 100 hours in this game can be crucial and dissapoiting. But when you accept the challenge and get into that game you will get a lot back.

												 Im pretty sad to see this game in the shape that its in currently. I pre-ordered ns2 before it came out and have played atleast 2000+ hours on ns1. I played probably 2 hours and then quit, completely dishearted at the lack of community and servers. I mostly played co maps, but did play ns maps about a quarter of the time. 												It's not bad. I loved the mod, this is alright. THey made their own Engine here...It's fun, but Aliens are very overpowered right now, will need a lot of balancing. Basically, as a Marine, with starter weapons, you need 10 dead accurate shots on a Skulk to kill him, now, the net code is flimsy, the skulk is very fast, and he can kill you in 1-2 hits, and his bites are faster than bullets, no joke.Then there are Fades...which are basically game over for Marines. Performance is really bad. They've worked on it, but I have a GTX670 SLI, 2500K @4.5GHZ, 8GB RAM, 128GB SSD, Windows 7 64-bit system and I struggle to maintain 60FPS and while the game is pretty, the levels are smaller than Counter-Strike or Call of Duty.

content:
Posted: May 5, 2016
												Update 10/05/2016Be sure to search for WOOZAS SERVER!Change Serverbrowser filter to ALL for an incredible experience of large scale natural selection 2 with 21vs21 and 16vs16!---------Update as of b297---------Since I changed my review to "not recommended", 3 patches have been released. Developer is stating on their forums: "We have no intentions to revert.", so this review will stay as "not recommended".Secondly, the original developer, UWE, has decided not to support their modding community and is actively seeking to kill certain modded servers. This is ridicolous coming from a game that was initially a mod to half life. Shame on you UWE.Also, the utter disrespect of how some members of the development team treat their community is astonishing. One developer posted on their official forum "I want to see your server (ns2large) a slow and painful death." that's no way to treat your community and buyers should be aware of this.I still recommend this game to friends, because it's a gem. But the incredible hatred and disrespect of some members of the development team is incredible and disgusts me.---------New Review as of b294---------Okay, so since my last review a lot has changed. Don't get me wrong, this is still the most amazing game I have encountered as of yet! I still enjoy playing NS2 but since UWE, the original developer of the game decided to "reanimate NS2", a lot has changed.NS2, at least what it was before UWE took back on the child they abandoned, was amazing. And I was actually kind of happy when UWE anounced to take NS2 back into their own hands and try to make something out of NS2. But it's gone completely wrong.All that UWE patching has brought us is:- We now have more paid skins, so YAY (which I bought, because I wanted to support the idea. I honsetly regret buying them now!)- We have useless collectible items that do nothing at all. Yay.- We have more bugs than we have before.- Most importantly: Server admins cannot control when patches are being installed and what they change. This is quite difficult for modded servers, as the patches ♥♥♥♥ up the modded servers on a regular basis. Admins do their best to clean up after UWE, but it's a pain in the ♥♥♥♥ and shows the complete disrespect of UWEs towards their community. The community that believed in NS2 when UWE abandoned it. It's a ♥♥♥♥ing punch in the face.And finally the reason why I changed my review: UWE thinks they know better, what new NS2 players want. They want to make NS2 more accessible for new players, so they decided to get rid of "large" severs.Now the logic behind this is: NS2 was originally made for small games, 7vs7 at the most. But there were mods for NS2, that allowed 16vs16 and even 21vs21. Obviously these are the servers I talked about when I referred to the patching issues, as all of the optimisation was done by the administrators and developers of NS2large. Now UWE thinks, large servers give the wrong impression to NS2 newcomers. I concur. And here's why:When I was new to NS2, I decided I did NOT want to join a small server like 7vs7, because I did not want to ♥♥♥♥ up, because of my noobidity. So I decided to join larger servers, hoping my noobishness would not impact as much on the outcome of the game. Now though, UWE is forcing new players to small servers, because they cannot find big servers anymore, as they are now in a new "tab", which I found hard to find in the first place. Essentially they are saying that NS2large is inofficial and move it to a different tab, even though 30-40% of the NS2 playerbase was playing NS2large. Noobs will not find it there and as of now, they do not - most large servers are empty when they were full before b294.So here's whats going to happen. Noobs will flood small servers, have a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ game because they get yelled at by veterans because they ♥♥♥♥ up, leave and say "NS2 has a horrible community and I did not understand a ♥♥♥♥ing thing". If they actually had the chance to learn what NS2 is, by joining larger servers where people tell them how things work and their newbness has little impact on the outcome of the game, some may become regulars. Those who think they're good enough to play smaller servers will do so anyway, so why take away the players choice? I honestly don't understand that and I feel separated from the NS2 community, because I prefer playing on larger servers. Even after 1000 hours, I still prefer the larger servers and I had the feeling that most newbs felt more comfortable on those servers too.So UWE, get your ♥♥♥♥ together and revert that server browser "upgrade". You're killing NS2 if you kill the large servers.---------original Review---------The learning curve is steep, but once you've got the basics, you have hundreds/thousands of hours ahead of you where you will get better and better just because you play more. It's an amazing game and a real gem. The community is alive and very friendly. Try it on "rookie friendly" servers. It's definitely not for casual gamers. Any negative review with less than 100 hours is from someone who's never gotten past the basics.

content:
Posted: September 24, 2016
												I don't know what you guys are thinking making your reviews negative even though you're posting positive reviews (not like that hurts the game or anything.. Hint hint, make more positive reviews). But, on to the inexperienced review.Now, I haven't been playing for super long like most players with 1000+ hours. But I do find myself at least moderate at the game, like I know what i'm doing but i still got much to learn. It's been a fun yet sometimes frusterating experience (Salty players and commanders of the sort, and my personal opinion on balance but let's not get into that). With it's small and ever so slowly dwindling community, I find this game really enjoyable and it's community equally enjoyable. It has an amazingly thoughtout RTS/FPS Hybrid gamestyle, confusing at first but easy to get a hang of. You can be a Soldier/Alien and do the fighting/building. This is in FPS. Now for the Commanders, you play in RTS. You can tell your soldiers what to do, what to build. Both teams are balanced really well. Both teams have different play styles, strategies and what have you. Both require quite a bit of time to get good with (I still have 10% accuracy overall despite being a gamer for 18 years).Natural Selection 2 is still getting updates to this day, adding new content or tweaks here and there. Even though the game is quite old. If you're looking for an interesting take on FPS/RTS, with an amazing and helpful playerbase then Natural Selection 2 is here. Don't mind the reviews flagged as negative despite some being positive, this game still has a flourishing community, with competitive events and players playing every day.For $10.99 (CDN) this game is worth it. The time required to become a good player/pro might take a while, but it's all worth it in the end. We need more positive reviews to let this game's community grow and become big again. Stop giving it bad reviews if you're going to say ''Oh this game is dying, but it was fun and all'' or whatever. You're unintentionally hurting the game that way.Horribly made review over. Have a good day.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 23, 2015
												The game is pretty interesting when you get a chance to play it.So pros:+ interesting mechanics. Playing as the alien side is obviously very different from most FPS games. However, playing as the marines is ALSO very different, because you're fighting aliens. So instead of shooting one from behind cover/while running/etc. you watch the vents, ceiling and walls for skulk ambushes, try to hit those pesky super-speed flying lerks, or die if you get caught alone by a roaming fade. Or in a group, if you stumble into an onos.+ Lots of replayability. Mastering one type of alien is difficult enough. And you can focus on a different role each time you play. The same goes for marines, even though for them it's more like mastering different types of equipment, because they play very differently(heavy and slow exosuit, which requires support to repair it, or jetpack and flamethrower/grenade launcher, which allows you to jump around the place and dodge as fast as the aliens?).+Teamwork. Each team has a commander which coordinates the team. And that adds a very interesting aspect of teamwork many other games don't have. Constant communication and good strategies can lead to some really fun moments.+ Execution. Feels responsive, decent variety of aliens/weapons, levels are strange, yet interesting. Don't know where Im going half the time(keep running into dead-ends, even with the minimap), but I feel that's just because Im not used to them yet. But therein lies the problem. Getting to play it. Why?- (Main Problem) Very few servers that have players in them. Fewer that acctually match your skill level (especially if you're a rookie). Also, using "join server" is generally a bad idea. Got dropped into a Russian server. Can't speak Russian. Great, wasted the amount of time to load everything (which, by the way, takes a long bloody time). Checked server list. 3 other servers with decent ping live, all full. I guess i can't play the game them. Sad. Guess I'll play something else.- Long loading times. Seriously. Long enough to get really annoying. I've heard they were working to fix it but hey, hasn't happened yet at the time Im writing this yet. Loading here makes me remmember the times you could go make a cup of tea while your computer was loading. Could I make one while this game loads? Well, now there's an idea...- NOT noob-friendly. I was lucky enough to find a game early on where there were some really nice people playing, and both losing and winning was fun (which is rare, usually losing is annoying whatever people say). And they help me learn some things. Never found the server again. Everyone just ignores you on other servers, so not to feel useless (dying as a skulk for the n-th time) i just started playing gorge (at least i don't feel like a waste of space then, at least im building things!). A bit easier as a marine, still, takes time to get used to alien moving patterns and you'll be useless at the start, if your skill level is below the others you're playing with.Short summary:Interesting game, whether you like to play FPS with a twist as the marine, or fight marines as the alien. Sadly, few players and huge difficulty finding a game you would enjoy at a rookie level. Thus I wouldn't recommend it unless you want it badly enough to persevere the lack of decent servers and the large learning curve (which just requires a lot of practise I suppose).

content:
Posted: December 28, 2015
												I played NS1 and i was really looking forward to playing the second part. I love the game's concept of combining FPS with RTS ressource management. But unfortunately i can't recommend it because:-Quite high hardware requirements. My computer is not the newest but NS2 isn't either. I can run many games with compareable graphics quite smooth on at least mid-range quality settings. But there are many FPS drops and:-Frequent crashes. I wasn't even able to run the tutorial smoothly. At first i wasn't even able to load it. Had to find a workaround on the forum. I was then able to start it, only to discover that it crashed many times before i was able to finish the it. Unfortuneately the completed tutorial is a requirement for playing online, which would be no problem IF IT WORKED. I also found a workaround for this problem. Just to have more crashes during the first 5 minutes of playing online.I'm sorry. I wanted to give it a chance but with these technical issues it is unfortunately just plain trash. And not just on my PC. Friends of mine had the same issues.What a pity. Could have been a great game.

content:
Posted: June 14, 2015
												This game is awesome.There are two teams of about 8 people (haven't played in a while) whereof one can become the commander.For the marines: The commander can tell the marines what buildings to build (in base and resource buildings), he can research new weapons and he can give ammo/healtpacks along the way.For the aliens: The commander can build buildings and research new aliens.This game is all about teamwork. Without, you will not win.Herefor most of the players playing will actually listen to their commander and group up with teammates instead of wandering on their own, which greatly increases the amount of fun I have when I'm playing.If you're in for some serious teamwork (and maybe some serious commanding) and like FPS games than this is the game for you.Ooh, the graphics are also FANTASTIC.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 24, 2016
												I recently bought this game, having really wanted it. After playing through the extremely basic tutorial, I headed off to multiplayer, being weary because I've heard this game isn't very noob friendly. At first, people guided me and helped out. I was thinking: "Wow, this is actually nice. They aren't cussing me out because I'm bad, and their actually giving me tips!" However, that was about the end of my enjoyment. After a few rounds, a few people left, a few people joined, and began cussing me out for not being good enough. I figured, fair enough, not everyone is nice. I'll just go practice with bots until I get the mechanics down a bit.... Terrible idea. The bots in this game are so terrible they might as well not even be there. Alien bots: They refuse to evolve, and I don't think they get any traits either. They also, for some ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ reason, refuse to target ANY marine structure. They have an extractor right next to your base? Guess what, they won't go after it. It will live on, never to be destroyed unless you destroy it. They also seem to be able to magically bite 5 times in 1 second, killing you pretty much instantly if they get to you.Marine bots: Each one of them has a mind of it's own... For the worse. They scatter, have no focus, and unless you're there with them, they won't build any extractors or power generators. Which leads me to something that I noticed while playing as an alien: They will destroy your harvestors, START to build an extractor, and then never finish it, leading to a very, very frustraiting bug: a hologram will just sit there, blocking you from building a harvestor, but indestructible (I got out of the hive, attacked it, but to no avail; every time it got close to being destroyed, a huge cloud of dust appeared and it would be back to the same health I found it at, about 1/4th full). Also, while playing a gorge, I blocked off an entrance to a room with clots. The marines seemed to not understand that they could destroy them, and just kept walking into them like they weren't there. This kept the hive alive for a long, long time, until I got bored and moved the clots somewhere else, and the entire marines team ran into the room immidiately.Mechanics: They seem fine, but I have one annoying nitpick: Scrolling down while your a marine goes to the melee weapon immidiately then your secondary weapon... Scrolling up goes to your secondary weapon, then your melee weapon... That makes no sense to me, and I'll probably never get used to that.For right now, I cannot reccomend this game. It seems like fun if you've played a lot of it and have gotten pretty good, but if you're starting out, it ends up being really frustraiting and unplayable. You can't really learn much while on multiplayer (especially when you want to try out being a commander, you'll get immidiately booted), and bots will make your worse at the game. (Or feel better about your skills, seeing how bad they are.)
